dialogues.text: Mommy, he smells.

(pause) The urgency is that the poor guy has been sitting like this for half an hour... (pause) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 24 No I will tell his son today that I can’t anymore... (pause) Yes... Yes.. All right. Thank you very much. Sorry to have bothered you. Goodbye. Razieh hangs up and goes into the kitchen and gets a pair of gloves.

dialogues.speaker: SOMAYEH
dialogues.text: I won’t tell daddy.

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: My little angel. Razieh goes into Mr. Morteza’s room and closes the door. Somayeh is curious and walks towards the door. Termeh pays the gas station attendant and quickly gets in the front passenger side and gives back the gas card to her father.

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH
dialogues.text: (getting in the car) Everyone is looking...

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: That’s okay sweetheart. How many?

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH
dialogues.text: Thirty-seven and a half...

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Did you get the change?

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH
dialogues.text: 25 He didn’t give me any...

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Did you ask for it?

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH
dialogues.text: It’s his tip.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: A tip is for when he pumps the gas.. you’ll go back and get it back... quickly. Termeh gets out and walks towards the attendant. dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Keep it. INT. NADER’S HOUSE — LIVING ROOM AND MR. MORTEZA’S ROOM —

dialogues.speaker: AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: Nader and Termeh rush in. Nader is holding a newspaper. MRS. GHAHRAEI is sitting behind the dining room table. Sh rises when Nader walks in. Razieh is in the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: (to Mrs. Ghahraei) Hello... Sorry we're late.

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GHAHRAEI
dialogues.text: Hello... How are you Termeh?

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH
dialogues.text: I’m well. I’1l go get my books.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GHAHRAEI
dialogues.text: And your test results.  26 Termeh goes to her room to take her bag and bring back he math books. Nader takes off his coat while walking toward his father’s room to give him the newspaper he has bought him. Somayeh is sitting next to Mr. Morteza and is readin the paper for him.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: (to his father) How are you? Good? (to Somayeh) How are you little lady? Are you reading the paper for him or is he reading it for you?

dialogues.speaker: MR. MORTEZA
dialogues.text: Has Ali gotten married?

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Who’s Ali?

dialogues.speaker: MR. MORTEZA
dialogues.text: Ali.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: (jokingly) Yes dad... and now it’s your turn. Mr. Morteza laughs from the bottom of his heart. Somayeh embarrassed and leaves the room. Razieh comes out of the kitchen and puts on her chador and gets ready to leave.

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: (to Somayeh) Come put your shoes on. We’re leaving.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GHAHRAEI
dialogues.text: (to Somayeh) Don’t forget your drawing. Somayeh collects her drawing and crayons from the dining room table.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GHAHRAEI
dialogues.text: Look after your mom okay?

dialogues.speaker: SOMAYEH
dialogues.text: 27 Okay. Somayeh places her drawing and crayons in her backpack. Nader comes out of Mr. Morteza’s room.

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Hello.. You hadn’t tightened the oxygen valve all the way.

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: I did in the morning.. he must’ve opened it.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: From now on tighten it all the way so that he can’t open it.

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: Excuse me but I might not be able to come here tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: (surprised) You had said you would come every day!

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: The commute is too far.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: I turned someone else away. It’s 4 pm. how can I find someone now for tomorrow morning?

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: The work is too much for me.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Please come here... Nader goes to the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: SOMAYEH
dialogues.text: 28 (pointing to her shoe) I can’t get it on my foot. Razieh helps her get her shoe on.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GHAHRAEI
dialogues.text: Maybe you got tired cause it was your first day.

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: No ma’am... (pointing to Mr. Morteza’s room) No. You were here for a few minutes. You saw.. I can’t with my situation. (to Somayeh) Get your bag.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GHAHRAEI
dialogues.text: Here’s that doctor’s number.

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: Is it a man or a woman?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GHAHRAEI
dialogues.text: A woman. Her secretary knows me. Tell them Ghahraei sent you. They also do sonograms.

dialogues.speaker: SOMAYEH
dialogues.text: It was kicking in mommy's tummy.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GHAHRAEI
dialogues.text: Cause he wants to come out and play with you.

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: It moved a lot today.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GHAHRAEI
dialogues.text: Then it’s definitely a boy. Razieh laughs and goes to the kitchen. Termeh comes back with her books and notebooks and sits at the dining room table next to Mrs. Ghahraei.  INT. KITCHEN — AFTERNOON 29 Nader is pouring water in the tea maker. He presses the button to boil the water. Razieh is standing in the doorw to the kitchen. Nader is looking for tea in the kitchen cupboards to refill the tea canister.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: You had to tell me yesterday. How can I leave him at home alone tomorrow? (to Termeh) Termeh, where does your mom keep the tea?

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: You didn’t tell me that I have to clean him.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Clean him?

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: He soiled his pants today. Nader stop looking in the cupboards and upset, Razieh.

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: It’s not right for me to clean him. Please pay me for today so I can go. Nader is deep in thought.

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: Could you pay me...

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Could you at least come tomorrow so that I have a chance to find someone else? I have to place an ad in the paper. looks at  30

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: There are companies you can call for a male helper.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: I can’t just let anyone into my home. Nader takes out some money out of his pocket and pays Razieh. Razieh takes the money and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: Goodbye. Nader comes to the kitchen. He hears the doorbell. He ope the door. Razieh is at the door.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: Excuse me but could I give my husband your number and say I found it in the paper so that he could come for this job?

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: You tell him about the job and if he was willing...

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: I don’t want him to know that you know me. I didn’t tell him I was coming here for work.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Tell him to call and come see me tonight...

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: It’s late for tonight. I’11l come tomorrow. Tell him to start from the day after tomorrow. And for the pay...

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: 31 Okay. Tell him to call me. We’ll arrange to meet at the bank.

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Bye and thanks for today. Razieh goes down the stairs. Nader goes back in and close the door. EXT. BUS STATION — AFTERNOON In the commotion of one of the city’s squares, Razieh and Somayeh, exhausted, are seated on the bench at the bus station. INT. BANK — DAY The guard opens the door. HOJJAT, Razieh’s husband who is thin thirty-seven-year-old man enters and walks towards t counter. Hojjat sits down by one of the desks and is looking inside the vault room and the stacks of cash, whi Nader is busy counting. Nader signs off on the vault’s en of the day count and walks towards the bank manager’s des

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: HOJJAT
dialogues.text: (recognizes Nader) Hello sir. Nader places the vault paperwork on the bank manager’s de and walks towards his own desk.

dialogues.speaker: HOJJAT
dialogues.text: Sorry I’m a little late.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: That’s okay. Where did you say you worked before?

dialogues.speaker: HOJJAT
dialogues.text: I was a cobbler.  32

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: And now you are not working?

dialogues.speaker: HOJJAT
dialogues.text: Yes, I am unemployed.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: And you're okay with cleaning him? Since yesterday he’s been soiling himself.

dialogues.speaker: HOJJAT
dialogues.text: No that’s no problem. I'11 treat him like my own father...

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: But you’1ll be alone with him and you have to really watch him.

dialogues.speaker: HOJJAT
dialogues.text: Your wife won’t be there?

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: No, I am alone for the moment.

dialogues.speaker: HOJJAT
dialogues.text: Excuse me but isn’t 300,000 too little for this work?

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: How much did you have in mind?

dialogues.speaker: HOJJAT
dialogues.text: I’ve worked for 15 years as a cobbler. If it’s one thing I’m not scared of it’s work. I can’t stand lazy people. I think you should at least pay 400,000...

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: I really can’t pay that.

dialogues.speaker: HOJJAT
dialogues.text: I’1l come for a few days. If you like my work, add something (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 33 to the 300,000. If not you don't even have to pay. I can even start today.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: No there’s someone there today. I’1l write down the address for you. Start tomorrow and bring an ID.

dialogues.speaker: HOJJAT
dialogues.text: Okay. Nader writes down the address. INT. NADER’S HOUSE — KITCHEN AND LIVING ROOM — MORNING Nader is standing next to the table. Termeh’s textbook is on the table. dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Constant?

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH
dialogues.text: Continuous.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Barren?

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH
dialogues.text: Sandbar.

dialogues.text: (correcting her) Desert!

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH
dialogues.text: Desert.

dialogues.text: Insurrection?

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH
dialogues.text: Rebellion. The doorbell rings.  34

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: (continues quizzing tone) Doorbell? Termeh is dressed in her school uniform and is putting on her shoes. She goes towards the intercom.

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH
dialogues.text: (continues quiz answering tone) Mrs. Razieh.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: (continues quizzing tone) No!

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH
dialogues.text: (continues quiz answering tone) Her husband. Termeh buzzes Razieh and her daughter in without checking to see who it is.

dialogues.text: Nemunak.

dialogues.speaker: NADER

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH
dialogues.text: Khoshaab.  35 Nader comes out of the kitchen with the book in his hand. He puts on his shoes to leave. He looks at his father who is asleep in his room.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Guarantee?

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH
dialogues.text: Tazmin, zemanat.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: That’s Arabic. The Persian version.

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH
dialogues.text: That’s what’s written in our book.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: I thought we agreed that you would never repeat that sentence. When something is wrong, it doesn’t matter where it’s written. For guarantee write... Nader thinks for a bit.

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH
dialogues.text: She’1l deduct points if I write anything else.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: That’s okay let her... write poshtvaneh. The doorbell rings. Termeh opens the door. Razieh and her daughter come in.

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Hello ma’am.. Your husband was supposed to come today!  Termeh leaves. 36

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: He couldn’t make it.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: What about tomorrow? Will he come?

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: I don’t know, if he doesn’t I‘1l come.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: I hope it’s not going to be like this everyday.

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: No poor guy wanted to come. Last night one of his creditors came with a police officer and took him away.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Yes but if something comes up and he can’t make it, I need to know a couple of days in advance.

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: No he will definitely come. I‘1l go see the creditor and ask to have him agree to release him. His check has bounced. He hadn’t come home for a week for fear of being arrested.

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH, (0.S.)

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: (quietly) Somayeh! She starts clearing the breakfast table. INT. MR. dialogues.speaker: SOMAYEH
dialogues.text: (to Mr. Morteza) Hello.

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Somayeh! Somayeh quickly leaves the room. INT. HALLWAY — DAY Somayeh comes out of Mr. Morteza’s room. Razieh is foldin up the rugs in the hallway, which were soiled two days earlier.

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: Take the trash out. Somayeh goes towards the garbage bag. Razieh is holding t rug and is dragging it to the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: Can you manage? Just leave it by the door. Somayeh picks up the garbage bag with difficulty and take it outside. Razieh pulls the rug into the bathroom. INT. dialogues.text: 38 the bottom of the bag pour out onto the stairs. Somayeh tries to pick up the garbage with her hands and get it ba into the bag but she can’t. INT. BATHROOM — DAY Razieh has placed the rug inside the bathtub and despite the fact that this is very difficult for her, she is tryi to wash and rinse it. Somayeh comes to the bathroom door.

dialogues.speaker: SOMAYEH
dialogues.text: Mommy, it got ripped!

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: (frustrated) Ah!... Where?

dialogues.speaker: SOMAYEH
dialogues.text: On the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: (angry) Why did you get it on your clothes? Where the hell am I going to get you clean clothes? Take it off! Razieh is angry at the situation that has occurred. Somayeh is wearing one of Termeh’s clothes, which is too big for her She comes to the doorway with a worried look on her face.

dialogues.speaker: SOMAYEH
dialogues.text: Mommy... he’s not in his room.

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: (worried) Go see if he’s in the bathroom.  39 Somayeh goes back inside. Razieh is worried. She leaves t garbage and is waiting for Somayeh to come back. She runs to the side of the street and then goes back to Nader’s street. She stops to catch her breath. Sh doesn’t know in which direction and where to look. She spots a newspaper stand at the end of the street and she sees Mr. Morteza standing next to it barefoot. He is tryi to cross the busy street. Horrified, she runs towards him She is looking at him and crossing the street when she hears the sound of screeching tires from behind. INT. NADER’S HOUSE - TERMEH’S ROOM — DAY Nader, Termeh, Somayeh and Mr. Morteza are playing tablet football and making a lot of noise. INT. KITCHEN — DAY Razieh washes her tired face at the kitchen sink. STAIRWAY — DAY Razieh opens the door. Tired, she walks down the stairs with her daughter. INT. BUS — EXT. STREET — AFTERNOON A bus is approaching the station. dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 40 among the other women. The bus drives off. Razieh is holding the bar and is tired. She feels dizzy and almost falls. A woman behind her holds her up. Another woman stands up and gives up her seat to Razieh.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN ON THE BUS
dialogues.text: Come and sit down. Razieh sits down and closes her eyes out of exhaustion. INT. NADER’‘S HOUSE — STAIRWAY — DAY MRS. KALANI, the upstairs neighbor, is standing outside Nader’s apartment and is talking to Mr. Morteza whose distorted silhouette can be seen from behind the glass door.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. KALANI
dialogues.text: Have you had your breakfast? Go sit down and I’1l1 call your son. Don’t go in the kitchen. Upset, Mrs. Kalani climbs up the stairs. The sound of the main door to the building is heard. She comes back down t stairs and waits to see who is coming up the stairs. Razi and Somayeh are climbing the stairs. Razieh is climbing t stairs with difficulty.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. KALANI
dialogues.text: My child, this poor old man has been standing by the door for half an hour. Why are you so late?

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: My commute is far.. hello.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. KALANI
dialogues.text: Hello. Razieh gets the key from the ledge above the door.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. KALANI
dialogues.text: And take the trash out with the can. The liquids pour out of the bag allover the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: 41 Yesterday I felt dizzy and dropped the bag. I’1l mop the stairs today. Razieh opens the door. Razieh and Somayeh go in and take Mr. Morteza with them. Some of the students are surrounding her and walking with her to her car. Termeh is among them. She is showing Mrs. Ghahraei a model she has made for her final. INT. NADER’S HOUSE — STAIRWAY — DAY Nader is holding Termeh’s backpack and is going up the stairs ahead of her. Termeh is holding the paper. They reach the apartment door. Nader rings the doorbell. Terme is tired and bends over to sit on the steps.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Don’t sit there, it’s wet. Termeh leans against the wall. Nader again rings the doorbell. No one answers. He tries the handle. He knocks the door. He is perplexed.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Ma’am.. ma’ am... (louder) Ma’‘am! He reaches up on the ledge to look for the key. He does n find it.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: What was her daughter’s name?

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH
dialogues.text: Somayeh.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: 42 Somayeh... Somayeh... Nader is worried. He presses his ear to the door to see i he might hear something. Nader faces the stairs to the floor above.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Mrs. Kalani... Mrs. Kalani... He climbs several steps. Termeh goes to the door. The neighbor’s

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH
dialogues.text: Grandpa... grandpa... door opens. Nader goes up a couple of steps.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Mrs. Kalani?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. KALANI, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Yes. Hello.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Hello. Did you see the woman who works for us?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. KALANI, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: She was mopping the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: When?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. KALANI, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Just before noon... she’s not home?

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: No... (to Termeh) Stay here, I’ll get my key from the car. Nader rushes down the stairs. INT. HALLWAY AND MR. MORTEZA’S ROOM — DAY The sound of the key in the keyhole. The door opens and (CONTINUED )

dialogues.text: 43 Nader and Termeh enter their house. No one is at home. Th door to Mr. Morteza’s room is locked. Nader unlocks the door and enters the room with Termeh. Mr. Morteza has fallen off his bed. One of his hands is tied tightly with scarf to the bar at the headboard. He has soiled his pant and his false teeth have fallen out of his mouth. It is clear that he has been left this way for a long time. Nad is distraught at seeing his father in this state. He hold his father’s head and looks at his face. Mr. Morteza’s ey are moving. He is alive. Termeh tries to untie her grandfather’s hand from the bed. Nader helps his father s on the edge of the bed. He is angry. Termeh is on the ver of tears.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Dad... dad... Termeh picks up her grandfather’s glasses from the floor.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Watch him... (while leaving) Shameless! Nader quickly leaves the room. He is angry. INT. MASTER BEDROOM — DAY Nader is hurriedly looking through the bedside table and vanity drawers where valuable documents, money and some gold are kept. He looks into another drawer in which some cash is kept. He counts them. Some is missing.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Did you take money from the drawer?

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: No. INT. HALLWAY — DAY Nader comes out of his room. He is going towards the kitchen when he spots Somayeh’s backpack left in a corner by the apartment door. He looks into the kitchen. INT. MR. MORTEZA’S ROOM — DAY  44

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Who did this to you? Mr. Morteza stares blankly at Nader.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Stand up. Stand up. Nader holds his father under his arms to help him stand. lifts his arms up and back down again to make sure he is not hurt.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Move your arms... raise them... do they hurt? Walk a little.. walk... raise your leg.. does it hurt anywhere? Nader helps his father take a few steps. Termeh is worrie about her grandfather. Mr. Morteza cannot walk easily.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: What’s wrong dad? Does your leg hurt? Nader seats his dad at the edge of the bed. He unbuttons his shirt and undresses him. He examines his body to make sure he is not hurt. Nader tries to take his father’s pan off. His father is clinging on to his pants. Termeh is standing there on the verge of tears.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: I want to see if you're okay.. let go... Nader realizes Mr. Morteza is embarrassed of Termeh.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: (to Termeh) Go stand outside.

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH
dialogues.text: Is he hurt?

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: No... go outside.  45 Termeh leaves the room. Nader takes off his father’s soil pants and holds him to take him out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: (loud to Termeh) Go to the kitchen and close the door. INT. KITCHEN AND HALLWAY — DAY Through the half open door, Termeh can see her father holding her grandfather like a child and taking him to th bathroom. She closes the door and bursts into tears.

dialogues.speaker: NADER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Bring me his clothes. EXT. BALCONY — DAY Termeh gathers her grandfather’s clothes and towel from t clothesline. INT. HALLWAY — DAY — CONT. Razieh and Somayeh hurriedly enter the house. She is worried to see that the door is unlocked and that Nader a Termeh’s shoes are by the door. She enters. She looks at Mr. Morteza’s empty room. She is clearly scared. Termeh walks into the hallway from the kitchen with Mr. Morteza’ clothing and towel. Happy, Somayeh runs towards her.

dialogues.speaker: SOMAYEH
dialogues.text: Hello. Cold and indifferent, Termeh walks towards the bathroom. From her reaction, Razieh realizes that the situation is not a good one. Somayeh wants to follow Termeh.

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: Come here. Somayeh stays. Razieh walks towards the kitchen and Somay follows her.

dialogues.speaker: SOMAYEH
dialogues.text: Mommy, I’m thirsty.  46 INT. KITCHEN AND HALLWAY — DAY Razieh is worried about Nader and Termeh’s presence in th house. She takes a glass and fills it from the tap and gives it to Somayeh to drink. Upset and angry, Nader come to the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Where’ve you been?

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: Something came up. I had to leave for a bit.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: You had no right to leave!

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: He was asleep.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: So if he was asleep you should lock him in and leave?

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: I wasn’t gone long.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: (angry) Not gone long? You’re standing there, looking into my eyes and lying? (angrier) He was dying when I got home.

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: I thought he would sleep like he does everyday.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: So then when he sleeps, you should lock him up and leave?  47 Razieh is quiet and a little shocked at Nader’s furious manner. Somayeh is drinking her water and is scared of Nader.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: I’m talking to you!

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: Has something happened to him?

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Why did you tie his hand to the bed... huh? Somayeh holds the empty glass towards her mother. Somayeh leaves

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: What is your responsibility in this house? To tie this poor man’s hand to the bed, lock him up and go after your own chores?

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: I had to go.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Didn’t I give you money? Why’ve you gone to the drawer and taken money?

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: (shocked) I took money?!

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: (to Razieh) Go on. Get out.

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: (to Somayeh) Go wait outside till I come. the house.

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: When did I take money?  48

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: You didn’t take money? Just get the hell out!

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Dad... come on.

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: On the holy martyrs I didn’t... here, search my bag if there was any money...

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Get out!

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: (on the verge of tears) You don’t want to give me what I’ve earned? Nader goes towards her to get her out of the house.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: What you’ve earned is a kick out of here.. it’s because your child is here that I’m not doing it. Get out!

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: (yelling) Don’t touch me!

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Then get out on your own! Nader forces her to get out. He follows her to the door a slams the door behind her.

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Dad... INT. CORRIDOR AND BATHROOM — DAY Nader walks towards the corridor in which the bathroom is located.

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH
dialogues.text: 49 He’s sitting behind the door. He won’t move back. Nader tries to push the door open but his father is sitti behind it and won’t let it open.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Go back so I can open the door... get up.. get up and move back... Dad... Nader tries to push his hand in through the door and push back his father who is sitting behind the door. He sits down to do this. Termeh is worried and standing above her dad. The sound of Razieh knocking on the door is heard. Nader pushes the door and hears his father moan.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Dad move over a little!.. look what’s that over there? The sound of the knocking is louder and Nader is getting angrier and more frustrated.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: (frustrated) Dad you’re wearing me out. Go back... (angry) Aren't I telling you to get back? (loud)

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH
dialogues.text: Why are you screaming? He doesn’t understand.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: (to Termeh) Didn’t I tell you to watch him? (to his father) Get up!

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH
dialogues.text: Maybe his leg is hurt and he can’t get up.  50

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: (with a threatening tone at his father) Get back! Get back I said! Nader is forced to push the door open. The door opens suddenly and his father is pushed to the bathroom floor. The doorbell rings.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: (to his father) Why do you hurt me so much? Mr. Morteza is staring at Nader with a blank look on his face. Now the sound of Razieh knocking at the door has driven Nader insane. Angry, he comes out of the bathroom. INT. CORRIDOR AND STAIRWAY — DAY Razieh opens the door to the apartment and walks in.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: (angry at Razieh) With whose permission did you come in?

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: (worried) I want to know what has happened to him.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: That’s none of your business! Give me that key and get out!

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: I didn’t steal anything. If I had...

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: I don’t want you to explain. Just get out.

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: Pay me for today and I'll leave.  51 The sound of the neighbor’s door opening.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Pay you for what?

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: (on the verge of tears) I come here with my child from... (crying) I swear on the prophet, I didn’t take any money.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Get out and cry all you want.

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: I won't leave till I get my money. Nader lunges towards her and grabs her by the shoulder to get her out.

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: (screaming) Don’t touch me! Nader pushes her out and slams the door shut and locks it Angry, he walks towards the corridor. Termeh is standing the corridor terrified and in disbelief. Nader goes into the bathroom. Termeh, worried, walks to the door and listens to see what has happened. Razieh’s voice has silenced. Worried, Termeh cracks the door open. She sees Razieh sitting at the foot of the stairs and is in such pain that she cannot even scream. Razieh can hardly breathe. Somayeh is standing above her mother and crying. neighbor, Mrs. Kalani is trying to help her. A couple of the neighbors are standing in the stairway. Mrs. Kalani i rubbing her shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. KALANI
dialogues.text: What happened? Razieh is trying to get up.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. KALANI
dialogues.text: Sit for a bit.. don’t get up...  52 Unaware of her surroundings, Razieh gets up with difficulty. Upset, she takes her daughter’s hand, gathers her chador around her and leaves. Upset, Termeh comes inside and closes the door. INT. BATHROOM — DAY Nader turns on the water. He holds the handheld shower ov his father who is sitting on the edge of the bathtub. He takes a loofah to wash him. While scrubbing him, he notic a wound on his father’s elbow. He starts to cry. He regre and is embarrassed by the way he earlier scolded his father. He holds his father’s head in his arms just like father would his child, kisses him. EXT. STREET OUTSDIE SIMIN’S PARENTS’ HOME — DUSK Nader is behind the wheel. His father is sitting quietly the front passenger seat. Termeh is in the back seat and has her schoolbag and an overnight bag with her. They dri up and stop outside an old apartment building. Termeh gathers her things to get out of the car.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Tell her to work with you on your English lessons.

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH
dialogues.text: Bye grandpa.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: (to his dad) Dad Termeh says bye. Mr. Morteza does not reply. Termeh gets out and jumps ove the street gutter and walks over to her grandmother’s house. Nader is waiting for her to go in. Termeh rings th doorbell. She speaks on the intercom. She then comes back to the street. Nader lowers his window. Termeh wants to cross and come over to the car.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Don’t cross... what is it?

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH
dialogues.text: Mom wants you to come in.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: 53 Tell her I can’t, that grandpa’s in the car.

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH
dialogues.text: She says it’s important. INT. SIMIN’S PARENTS’ HOUSE — NIGHT A simple and old apartment. GRANDMA KATTI (Simin’s mother opens the door on Nader. Simin’s dad who is seventy years old is seated on a chair in a corner and because of his ailing leg, is praying in that position. A young SATELLIT TV TECHNICAN is standing in front of the television set a is organizing the channels on the satellite TV receiver. Simin puts on a headscarf to come out of her room.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDMA KATTI
dialogues.text: Hello. You haven’t yet divorced your wife and you’re ignoring us.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: I’m busy.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDMA KATTI
dialogues.text: People divorce their wives to get less busy. Simin comes out of her room to the living room. Nader has taken a few steps inside the house. They are both ina sullen state and cold towards each other.

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: Where’s Termeh?

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Dad’s in the car. She stayed with him.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDMA KATTI
dialogues.text: Then bring him in too.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: No he’s tired. It’s time for his nap.  54

dialogues.speaker: SATELLITE TV TECHNICIAN
dialogues.text: Ma’am, these channels have too much static.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDMA KATTI
dialogues.text: Okay just set the ones you can.

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: (to Nader) Did you fight with that woman today?

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Which woman?

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: Razieh.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Did she come see you?

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: Her sister-in-law called.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Shameless!

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: What did she do?

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Tied the old man to the bed and locked the door. Went after her own errands. If I’d gotten there 10 minutes later I would've lost him.

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: (worried) Did anything happen to Dad?

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: He had fallen off the bed. I don’t know for how long the poor thing was like that.

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: 55 Where had she gone?

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: How should I know?

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: She said you hit her.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: I hit her? Nonsense.

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: Then why is she in hospital?

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: (shocked) Hospital? Why? What happened?

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: You’re asking me?

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: I just pushed her out of the house.

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: The sister-in-law was cursing me nonstop.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Saying what?

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: That if she dies, her blood will be on your hands. Stuff like that. Nader is clearly worried. SIMIN’S FATHER has finished saying his prayers. SIMIN’S FATHER Go to the hospital and find out what’s happened... you might be in trouble.. Hello.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: (to Simin’s father)  56 Hello. (to Simin) She didn’t say what happened?

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: I hung up. She started cursing. Frustrated, Nader sits down on the chair next to her.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: That’s what you get for hiring people off the streets.

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: Don’t blame me. I told Termeh to tell you that I don’t know her and only know her sister- in-law.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Which hospital is she at? INT. HOSPITAL — NIGHT In a hospital in the south of Tehran with dated interiors Nader walks towards the reception. Simin is behind him. A middle-aged woman is sitting at reception and is on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: (to Nader) Yes? (on the phone) Hold.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Excuse me but a patient, a woman, by the name of Razieh was brought in...

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: What’s her last name?

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: We don’t know her last name but she was brought in earlier this evening.  57

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Her husband’s family name is Samadi...

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: Why was she brought in? Nader and Simin don’t know what to say.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: We don’t know. We just heard that she is not well and that they’ve brought her here. The receptionist looks over her papers.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: (reading from one of the papers) Razieh... Asnaghi?

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: She is a woman in her thirties.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: Visiting hours are over. She’s had surgery and has been transferred to the ward.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: What kind of surgery?

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: She had a miscarriage. By hearing this news, Nader becomes extremely upset and moves to a corner and stands there.

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: Is she okay?

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: Yes, she’s fine.

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: Is her family here?

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: 58 They were here... they might be at the end of this corridor now. Simin walks towards Nader who is upset and standing in a corner.

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: What did you do to her?

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: (upset at Simin) What did I do to her? INT. END OF A CORRIDOR — NIGHT Several rows of benches are placed in a square-shaped are at the end of the corridor. A television set is installed on a column and is showing the news. The next of kin of patients are seated on the benches in silence and some of them have dozed off. Among them is Hojjat, Razieh’s husband. He is watching TV. Simin and Nader walk though t corridor to this waiting area. Nader spots Hojjat and cautiously approaches him. Nader is followed by Simin.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: HOJJAT
dialogues.text: Hello... How are... (he recognizes him) Hello... How are you?

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Thank you very much... How is she?

dialogues.speaker: HOJJAT
dialogues.text: (puzzled) Who?

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Your wife.

dialogues.speaker: HOJJAT
dialogues.text: They transferred her to the ward.. Did you know her?!  59

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: Yes... I knew her. Hojjat is a little suspicious. Nader and Simin, who weren expecting this calm reaction from him, do not know what reason to give for their presence at the hospital.

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: Can we see her? Hojjat’s sister, AZAM now arrives with some cake and frui juice. She knows Simin.

dialogues.speaker: AZAM
dialogues.text: (to Hojjat) They didn’t have any sandwiches.

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: Hello. Azam ignores her on purpose.

dialogues.speaker: HOJJAT
dialogues.text: (to Nader and Simin) How do you know my wife?

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: I know her through your sister. She introduced her to me for work.

dialogues.speaker: AZAM
dialogues.text: (sarcastically to Simin) Thanks a lot!

dialogues.speaker: HOJJAT
dialogues.text: (to Nader) She was coming to your house for work?

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Apparently you were unable to come so she came in your place.  60

dialogues.speaker: AZAM
dialogues.text: (to Hojjat) Sit down and eat something.

dialogues.speaker: HOJJAT
dialogues.text: (to Nader) She came to take care of your father?

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Only for a few days.

dialogues.speaker: HOJJAT
dialogues.text: And why didn’t you tell me this that day?

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: I thought she would tell you herself.

dialogues.speaker: HOJJAT
dialogues.text: Why have you come here?

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: We thought if there is something we can...

dialogues.speaker: AZAM
dialogues.text: Like what? You killed her child and now you want to raise her dead?

dialogues.speaker: HOJJAT
dialogues.text: (to Azam) But she said she fell!

dialogues.speaker: AZAM
dialogues.text: What did you want her to say? That I went somewhere and worked myself to death and instead of paying me they beat me. Upon hearing this Hojjat lunges at Nader catching him off guard and slaps him hard. Nader holds Hojjat’s hand to st him from hitting him again. Azam tries to stop Hojjat who is no longer in control. Simin stands in front of Nader t (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 61 stop Hojjat from hitting him. Other people surround them. One of Hojjat’s blows strikes Simin’s face and nose. Nade pushes Hojjat back and defends Simin. People take Hojjat the side. Hojjat yells and curses.

dialogues.speaker: AZAM
dialogues.text: (yelling at Nader) Why in God’s name did you come here? Worried, Simin takes Nader to another side. Nader doesn’t object and sits down in a corner. His shirt is torn.

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: Don’t sit here. Let’s go. Get up... Nader looks up and sees Simin bleeding from her nose. INT. NADER’S CAR — EXT. STREET — NIGHT Nader is behind the wheel with a disheveled look. Simin i sitting in the passenger side seat with her head tilted back. She is lightly bruised under her eyes. She is holdi a napkin to her nose.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Do you want me to push back you chair? Simin shakes her head to imply no.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: I’1l take you home and then I’1l go get Dad and Termeh.

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: What do you mean no?! You want to go to your parents’ in your state?! Simin doesn’t respond.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: 62 It’s over. You’re coming back home tonight.

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: I don’t want to. Nader is shocked at her response and doesn’t continue the discussion. INT. COURTHOUSE — CORRIDORS — DAY In the busy and crowded corridors of the courthouse, Nade is in search of the branch he has been summoned to. He is holding a piece of paper in his hand. Among the many face seated in the corridor, he spots Somayeh, Razieh’s daughter, sitting by herself. She is absorbed by the peop in handcuffs or in prison uniforms. Through a partially opened door, Nader spots Hojjat who is busy speaking to t examining magistrate’s assistant. A few feet behind him, Razieh standing next to the door. Nader waits for them to finish and come out before going inside. Now Somayeh sees Nader. She doesn’t know whether she should say hello or ignore him. Nader is looking at her kindly. Hojjat and Razieh come out of the room. They are not expecting to se Nader. They pass each other without any kind of exchange. Razieh still looks pale and sickly. Nader goes in. Hojjat looks at Nader hatefully. Razieh takes her daughter’s han and walk towards the door to leave but it seems like Hojj wants to stay. INT. EXAMINING MAGISTRATE’S ROOM — DAY In a room with a window, which opens to the crowded courtyard of the courthouse, Hojjat and Razieh are seated on chairs opposite the examining magistrate’s desk. Nader is seated two chairs over. Between them is an empty chair The door is ajar and the people and the traffic from the room next door are heard. The secretary who is a young ma is seated behind another desk and is on the phone. The EXAMINING MAGISTRATE makes notes according to their answers.

dialogues.speaker: EXAMINING MAGISTRATE
dialogues.text: So.. Mr. Hojjat Samadi and Ms. Razieh...

dialogues.speaker: HOJJAT
dialogues.text: Asnaghi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that you ma’am?

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: EXAMINING MAGISTRATE
dialogues.text: And you are Mr. Nader Lavasani.. (to Razieh) Okay so what’s your complaint?

dialogues.speaker: HOJJAT
dialogues.text: May I speak?

dialogues.speaker: EXAMINING MAGISTRATE
dialogues.text: You filed a joint complaint. Either of you may speak.

dialogues.speaker: HOJJAT
dialogues.text: My wife was working in this man’s home. Without my permission of course. This man accuses her of stealing. He pushes her down the stairs and she falls and loses my child.

dialogues.speaker: EXAMINING MAGISTRATE
dialogues.text: Do you have the medical examiner’s report?

dialogues.speaker: HOJJAT
dialogues.text: It’s on your desk.

dialogues.speaker: EXAMINING MAGISTRATE
dialogues.text: On what date was this?

dialogues.speaker: HOJJAT
dialogues.text: What date was Wednesday?

dialogues.speaker: EXAMINING MAGISTRATE
dialogues.text: (to Nader) You heard the accusation? Do you accept the charge? What is your defense?

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: (upset) 63  64 I am sorry, when I heard I was very upset. I got up and went to the hospital.

dialogues.speaker: EXAMINING MAGISTRATE
dialogues.text: Then you accept that you did this? (pointing to the medical examiner's report and to Hojjat) Did you get this on that day from the medical examiner’s office?

dialogues.speaker: HOJJAT
dialogues.text: That night we went to the hospital. We took the hospital file to the medical examiner's office.

dialogues.speaker: EXAMINING MAGISTRATE
dialogues.text: (reading from the report) Four and a half months... male... (to Nader) Well, explain.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: I accept that I was a little too harsh with her.

dialogues.speaker: EXAMINING MAGISTRATE
dialogues.text: What is harsh? Did you push this lady?

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: I didn’t push her. I tried to get her out of the house.

dialogues.speaker: EXAMINING MAGISTRATE
dialogues.text: Look sir. Please be clear. You've been charged with manslaughter. The fetus was at four-and-a-half months and counts as a complete human adult.  65 Nader is completely shocked at the magistrate’s words.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: I didn’t approach her with the intent of pushing her.. I wanted her to leave so that I could close the door to my house.

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: (shocked) You didn’t push me?!

dialogues.speaker: EXAMINING MAGISTRATE
dialogues.text: Ma’am, please.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: If I knew she were pregnant, I wouldn’t even try to get her out of the house like that. I just wanted her to leave.

dialogues.speaker: EXAMINING MAGISTRATE
dialogues.text: Ma’am Do you agree with his explanation?

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: He didn’t push me. He grabbed me here and threw me out and I fell on the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: I didn’t throw her. Like I said I wanted to get her to leave my house.

dialogues.speaker: HOJJAT
dialogues.text: You jerk, who gets a pregnant woman to leave their house this way?

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: I didn’t know she was pregnant.

dialogues.speaker: HOJJAT
dialogues.text: Why are you lying?

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: 66 I found out at the hospital.

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: Your honor, you’re like an older brother to me, can't everyone tell from the appearance and body of a woman that she is pregnant...

dialogues.speaker: HOJJAT
dialogues.text: 4 to 5 months pregnant.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: When did I even have a chance to see you? I was already gone or leaving when you'd arrive. When I’d come back in the afternoon, you always had your chador on and were leaving. In fact whenever I’d see you, you always looked like this with the chador. How would I know you...

dialogues.speaker: EXAMINING MAGISTRATE
dialogues.text: (to Razieh) He can claim that he couldn’t tell from your appearance.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Besides, your honor, I would never think that a pregnant woman would apply for this kind of work.

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: Your honor, I spoke of my pregnancy in front of him, his daughter and her private tutor who comes to their house. They all heard it.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: When? I don’t remember.

dialogues.speaker: HOJJAT
dialogues.text: No of course you wouldn't remember.  67

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Anyway, the issue isn't that I knew or not.

dialogues.speaker: EXAMINING MAGISTRATE
dialogues.text: Yes it is! If it’s proven that you knew, the court can sentence you to 1 to 3 years in prison... Well?

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: I didn’t know.

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: His daughter’s tutor can testify. Let her come in and say that he didn’t hear me.

dialogues.speaker: EXAMINING MAGISTRATE
dialogues.text: Can she come in tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Your honor, I don’t want her or the school involved. That’s not good for my child.

dialogues.speaker: HOJJAT
dialogues.text: (angry) You trash. You’ve killed my child. It's bad for your child?

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Don’t insult me.

dialogues.speaker: HOJJAT
dialogues.text: (a bit more calm) Your child is human but ours was an animal?

dialogues.speaker: EXAMINING MAGISTRATE
dialogues.text: (to Hojjat) Don't insult.

dialogues.speaker: HOJJAT
dialogues.text: Am I insulting or he who took (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Razieh has not 68 my poor pregnant wife to clean the shit between his father’s legs?

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Ma’am did I force you to come? You came for...

dialogues.speaker: EXAMINING MAGISTRATE
dialogues.text: (to Hojjat) Look, if you disrupt the order here, I ‘11 put you in prison for three days.

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: (to the Examining Magistrate) Please he's a bit hot-tempered...

dialogues.speaker: HOJJAT
dialogues.text: (to Razieh) Hot-tempered? I should sue you for secretly working for a strange, single man whom no one knows...

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: (in tears) I only wanted to help with the bills. Your honor, he hasn’t worked for months.

dialogues.speaker: EXAMINING MAGISTRATE
dialogues.text: The tutor has to come in as a witness. (to Nader) Call her to come in tomorrow or give her number to Mr. Izadi to arrange it. yet stopped crying.

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: Your honor I’m here today for one thing.. I lost my child but it didn’t hurt as much as when he accused me of being a thief...  69

dialogues.speaker: HOJJAT
dialogues.text: If we were thieves, we wouldn’t have to come to your homes for work.

dialogues.speaker: EXAMINING MAGISTRATE
dialogues.text: (to Nader) Do you have proof or a witness that she stole?

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: I didn’t say she stole? I went to my drawer, and saw that my money was short. And it was the same amount that I pay her.

dialogues.speaker: EXAMINING MAGISTRATE
dialogues.text: Why did you fight?

dialogues.speaker: HOJJAT
dialogues.text: He accused her of stealing.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Your honor, my father is 80 years old. He is sick. He has Alzheimer’s. She tied his hand to the bed and left the house. That day I came home early. I saw him on the floor with his hand tied to the bed. I thought he had died. She came back and I’m not saying I wasn’t angry, I was. I told her to leave and she was being stubborn and wouldn't leave.

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: Your honor, where should I have gone? He accused me of stealing. If I hadn’t asked for the money and left, he would’ve thought I had stolen the money.

dialogues.speaker: EXAMINING MAGISTRATE
dialogues.text: Was your father hurt?

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Yes he was a little hurt.  70 Razieh gets upset at hearing this. She looks at the windo and then gets up to leave the room.

dialogues.speaker: EXAMINING MAGISTRATE
dialogues.text: Ma’am sit down. Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: (pointing to the window) My daughter is going outside!

dialogues.speaker: EXAMINING MAGISTRATE
dialogues.text: Come back quick. And close the door. Razieh leave and closes the door behind her. INT. CORRIDORS — DAY With the excuse of checking up on her daughter, Razieh comes out of the examination branch and walks through the crowded and busy corridors towards the exit. She is preoccupied with something. EXT. COURTYARD — DAY She reaches the courtyard. She looks around and spots her daughter playing in a corner of the yard. She walks towar her. She spots a public telephone in the corner of the yard. Doubtful, she changes her direction and walks towar the public phone. She waits for the person who is on the phone to finish their conversation. She is a little worried. She gets a little notebook out of her bag. She uses her broken glasses to read a number out of it. Her turn to use the phone comes up. She dials the number. She is waiting for the other end to pick up. She sees Hojjat who has come to the courtyard looking for her. She hangs before Hojjat can see her and walks towards Hojjat.

dialogues.speaker: HOJJAT
dialogues.text: Why are you taking so long?

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: I’m not well. You go I'11l come.

dialogues.speaker: HOJJAT
dialogues.text: 71 He says you locked up his father and left.

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: What should I say?

dialogues.speaker: HOJJAT
dialogues.text: Say? If he files a complaint you'll be arrested. Razieh doesn’t know what to do. It is clear she is ina difficult situation.

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: You go on. I’11l come. Hojjat leaves. Razieh is upset and full of doubt. She goe back inside. Somayeh is standing in a corner and looking a small kitten that in the midst of all this commotion, i standing by a prisoner’s foot. The prisoner is in handcuf and is in prison uniform. A guard is sitting next to him. The prisoner is throwing his leftover food from a plastic plate on the ground for the little kitten. The kitten is eating it and rubbing itself against the prisoner’s leg. Somayeh is curious and walks towards them and stands ther and watches the kitten. INT. EXAMINING MAGISTRATE’S OFFICE — DAY Now, Nader, Hojjat and Razieh are all standing in front o the examining magistrate’s desk. They are all more distraught than before. The door is still open and other people waiting to see the magistrate are all standing in line by the door with their files in their hands.

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: He was sleeping. I locked the door to keep him in. His son would lock the door and leave me the key in the mornings. I saw that he does it so I...

dialogues.speaker: EXAMINING MAGISTRATE
dialogues.text: He says you tied him to the bed.

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: 72 I was afraid he would wake up and do something to hurt himself. I swear on the Absent Imam that I did it out of compassion for him.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: The question is why did you leave your place of work.

dialogues.speaker: HOJJAT
dialogues.text: So if she left you should hit her? Who said you could touch my wife? If honor’s not important for you, it is for me.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Don’t be offensive.

dialogues.speaker: EXAMINING MAGISTRATE
dialogues.text: (to Hojjat) Sir, leave the room... go on.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: I want to file a complaint against this woman.

dialogues.speaker: EXAMINING MAGISTRATE
dialogues.text: Write your complaint. Take your father to the medical examiner. If he’s hurt, get a report.

dialogues.speaker: HOJJAT
dialogues.text: What happens to our complaint?

dialogues.speaker: EXAMINING MAGISTRATE
dialogues.text: (to Hojjat) Sign this and leave.

dialogues.speaker: EXAMINING MAGISTRATE
dialogues.text: (to Nader) Call someone to post bail or bring a deed for you.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: (extremely shocked)  73 Bail for what?

dialogues.speaker: EXAMINING MAGISTRATE
dialogues.text: You’re charged with murder. I can’t let you leave. The blood money is forty-million tomans.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: How am I going to post bail or bring a deed? I live at my dad's.

dialogues.speaker: EXAMINING MAGISTRATE
dialogues.text: Without bail you’1ll go to jail... come and sign here. It is clear that Razieh is upset from the situation Nader is in. She comes forward with Hojjat and both sign the paperwork. Nader is helpless.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: (pleading) Your honor, my father is sick and he’s home alone right now. I couldn't find anyone to watch him. I had to lock him in and come here. My daughter will be back from school this afternoon. No one will be there to watch them. I’1l leave you my ID, my pay slips, whatever you want but if I go to jail my dad and my daughter... Please.

dialogues.speaker: EXAMINING MAGISTRATE
dialogues.text: Look sir, it’s not in my hands. It's the law. INT. EXAMINING MAGISTRATE’S MANAGER'S OFFICE — DAY Nader is on the phone. The room is crowded and other peop are all speaking to the office manager.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: (on the phone) What about the guys at the bank? (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 74 (pause) What about Tavassoli? (pause) In whose name is it? (pause) Is your wife home now? (pause) Can you speak to her? (pause) Please Bahman, just let me know ASAP. If the deed isn’t here in an hour, I have to go to jail... uhum.. if I call in ten minutes will you know? (pause) Okay. (pause) No thanks. Nader is very upset. He hangs up the receiver and again picks it up to call another number. The office manager objects.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICE MANAGER
dialogues.text: How many calls do you make?

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: I just want to leave a message.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICE MANAGER
dialogues.text: Hurry up so this place clears up. Nader takes the receiver and makes another call. He waits While he waits, he sees through the open door that Hojjat and his wife have not left yet. INT. NADER’S HOUSE — MR. MORTEZA’S ROOM, HALLWAY, KITCHEN NIGHT. Termeh comes out of the kitchen and goes to the bathroom wash her hands. Simin has come there and walks towards th answering machine. She listens to Nader’s message.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: (recorded message) Hello, Termeh.. I got tied up (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 75 here today. They’re keeping me tonight. Don’t worry about anything. It’s nothing. It’s just that tonight you’ll have to be on your own. Keep an eye on everything. Take grandpa to the bathroom regularly. Kisses. Take care. I’1ll call you again tomorrow. During the message’s entire playback, Simin gets up and walks toward Mr. Morteza’s room. Mr. Morteza is quiet and sometimes looks at Simin. Simin is in conflict with herself. Termeh comes out of the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH
dialogues.text: If you hadn’t left, Dad wouldn’t be in jail right now.

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: Your dad is not in jail because of what I did. It’s because he’s beaten up a pregnant woman like a thug.

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH
dialogues.text: She came cause you left.

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: (with sarcasm) And he was just so upset that I left.

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH
dialogues.text: He knew you weren’t really leaving. Simin falls silent for a moment. She is pensive.

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: Did you tell him?!

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH
dialogues.text: He found out.

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: Say the truth. You told him?  76 Termeh does not respond.

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: Get your stuff. We’re leaving...

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH
dialogues.text: I won’t come. I have homework to do.

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: I‘1l leave you and if you die of fright I...

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH
dialogues.text: Fine.

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: If you call I’m going to let you have it. Termeh does not respond. Simin sits Mr. Morteza down on t sofa and walks into the kitchen to get some things. INT. SIMIN’S CAR — EXT. STREET — NIGHT Mr. Morteza is sitting quietly on the passenger side chai He is staring ahead blankly. Simin is behind the wheel an is driving.

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: Not a word to say don’t do this, don’t leave or I won’t divorce you... Not a word... “One day you came to live with me and now you don’t want to!”.. It's not as if I lived with him for 14 years. A brief silence ensues. She is very upset.

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: If he'd say “I won't divorce you,” or he’d fight with me, or make excuses, it wouldn’t hurt this much... She now begins to cry.  77

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: Child! Only our child? That’s it? Whether I’m there or not it doesn’t matter... The entire time Simin is speaking, Mr. Morteza is staring at her. It is clear that he has not understood anything o what Simin has just said. Simin pulls over by the side of the street. She thinks a little. She is worried. She make a U-turn on that very busy street and goes back. EXT. COURTHOUSE — COURTYARD — DAY Nader is walking through the courtyard towards the building. He is handcuffed to an officer. From his expression it is clear that he has spent a difficult nigh in jail. Termeh seems to be waiting for him. Upon seeing him, she walks towards him. Nader is shocked to see her here.

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH
dialogues.text: Dad... Hi.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: What are you doing here? Who'd you come with? Termeh sees her father’s hand handcuffed to the young officer’s. She looks like she is going to cry and cannot say anything.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Why aren’t you at school? Didn’t you have an exam today?

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH
dialogues.text: No it's tomorrow. Nader, Termeh and the officer walk towards the building a the corridor.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Who brought you here?

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH
dialogues.text: Mom has brought Grandma’s deed.  78 Nader is a little surprised at hearing this. INT. CORRIDOR — EXT. COURTYARD — DAY Nader and Termeh enter the corridor. He glances at the other end of the corridor and sees Hojjat, his wife and their daughter sitting and waiting. Somayeh’s gaze is at Termeh. Nader sees Grandma Katti and along with Termeh an the officer, they walk towards her.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDMA KATTI
dialogues.text: Shouldn’t you tell us you’re in trouble so we can bring a deed?

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: I didn’t want to trouble you.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDMA KATTI
dialogues.text: Silly man.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: (to Termeh) Where’s grandpa?

dialogues.speaker: GRANDMA KATTI
dialogues.text: He’s safe. He’s at our house. Come and sit.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER
dialogues.text: No ma’am he can’t. I have to take him to the examining magistrate.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDMA KATTI
dialogues.text: (to Nader) What are they saying? “My child” as if their eighteen- year old son was stabbed to death on the street.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Did you speak to them?

dialogues.speaker: GRANDMA KATTI
dialogues.text: 79 You can’t even speak to the man. I told the wife you’re young. You can try next year. Honestly! Simin walks towards them with the deed and other document in her hand. She is still cold towards Nader.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDMA KATTI
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: I have to take someone to appraise the house.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: Hi. (to Grandma Katti and Termeh) You stay here. I’1l be back. Simin leaves. She walks from the corridor to the courtyar From her face, it is clear that she has had a difficult night. INT. SECURITY DESK — DAY The FEMALE OFFICER at security is looking through all the cell phones in her drawer to find Simin’s cell phone. Sim is standing in front of the desk waiting to get her cell phone before she leaves. Mrs. Ghahraei who has just walke in, sees her.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GHAHRAEI
dialogues.text: Hi Mrs. Lavasani. The female officer hands Simin her cell phone.

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: Hi. (to the female officer) Thank you. (to Mrs. Ghahraei) How are you?  80

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GHAHRAEI
dialogues.text: It’s a good thing I saw you. What happened? Is it true that...

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: Yes unfortunately. He pushed her and she fell and lost her baby.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GHAHRAEI
dialogues.text: (worried) So what should I tell them?

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: I don’t know what they’1ll ask.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GHAHRAEI
dialogues.text: What if he asks something that...

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE OFFICER
dialogues.text: (to Mrs. Ghahraei) Ma’am, your cellphone. Simin doesn’t know how to answer Mrs. Ghahraei’s question Mrs. Ghahraei hands over her cellphone to the female officer. Simin leaves.

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: (to Mrs. Ghahraei) You should tell the truth. (walking towards the exit) Excuse me but I have to go and take care of this deed.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GHAHRAEI
dialogues.text: Okay. INT. EXAMINING MAGISTRATE’S OFFICE — DAY Sitting in front of the examining magistrate’s office, ar Hojjat and Razieh. They are on one side of Mrs. Ghahraei and Nader is on the other. Mrs. Ghahraei is answering questions.  81

dialogues.speaker: EXAMINING MAGISTRATE
dialogues.text: Where was he?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GHAHRAEI
dialogues.text: Mr. Lavasani was in the Kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: EXAMINING MAGISTRATE
dialogues.text: Did he have any reaction or contribute to your conversation?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GHAHRAEI
dialogues.text: If he did, I didn’t notice.

dialogues.speaker: EXAMINING MAGISTRATE
dialogues.text: How did you realize she was pregnant?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GHAHRAEI
dialogues.text: I think she told me.

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: Ma’am you asked me. Why would I tell you?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GHAHRAEI
dialogues.text: Oh yes her daughter was drawing a man and a woman. She said this is my daddy and mommy. I said your mommy’s not that fat. She said she has a baby in her tummy.

dialogues.speaker: EXAMINING MAGISTRATE
dialogues.text: So you didn’t find out from her appearance?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GHAHRAEI
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: HOJJAT
dialogues.text: Why are you lying? You’re a woman. Women can tell from the face of a woman if she’s pregnant.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GHAHRAEI
dialogues.text: 82 Even if I could tell, what difference does it make to Mr. Lavasani?

dialogues.speaker: HOJJAT
dialogues.text: This woman is his daughter’s tutor. They’ve fixed their stories.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Why are you insulting this lady?

dialogues.speaker: HOJJAT
dialogues.text: No one’s talking to you.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: When did I have the opportunity to fix my story? I was in here last night!

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: Your honor, it is obvious. Now that I am speaking to you, even if that man... (pointing to the secretary) doesn’t want to, he can hear us. (to the secretary) Right?

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: I didn’t hear you. My mind is in a thousand places. Why would I listen to your conversation? Do I have to swear to God?

dialogues.speaker: HOJJAT
dialogues.text: Like you even believe in God and the prophet that...

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: No God and the prophet are for your type only!

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GHAHRAEI
dialogues.text: 83 (to the examining magistrate) He is an honorable man. I’ve been going there for a year to teach his daughter. He doesn’t come into the living room till I’m done teaching his daughter. He stays in his room.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Why when she’s pregnant would she not tell me about it? Why would she hide it and come and take this job? If I had known, I wouldn’t have even hired her.

dialogues.speaker: HOJJAT
dialogues.text: Why did you hire her when you knew she didn’t have her husband’s permission to work?

dialogues.speaker: EXAMINING MAGISTRATE
dialogues.text: (to Mrs. Ghahraei) You may go. INT. CORRIDOR — DAY Grandma Katti has her reading glasses on. She is taking this opportunity to quiz Termeh from her book. Termeh is sitting on one side of Grandma Katti and Somayeh is sitti to the other side with a slight space between them. She i curious about Termeh’s answers to her grandmother’s questions.

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH
dialogues.text: During the rule of the Sassanian Dynasty, people were divided into two classes, the royalty and nobility and the ordinary people.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDMA KATTI
dialogues.text: (correcting her) The common people. Mrs. Ghahraei walks out of the examining magistrate’s department and walks towards them.  84

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH
dialogues.text: Ma’am what did they ask?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GHAHRAEI
dialogues.text: They wanted to know whether your dad knew Somayeh’s mom was pregnant or not.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDMA KATTI
dialogues.text: We've caused you all this trouble.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GHAHRAEI
dialogues.text: There's nothing to forgive. (to Somayeh) Sweetie, how did mommy lose her baby?

dialogues.speaker: SOMAYEH
dialogues.text: She got a tummy ache.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GHAHRAEI
dialogues.text: Why?... Did daddy fight with her at home?

dialogues.speaker: GRANDMA KATTI
dialogues.text: (trying to get Somayeh to explain) Why should he fight with her?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GHAHRAEI
dialogues.text: (to Somayeh) Maybe because she didn’t tell him she was working in people’s home? Did he hit her?

dialogues.speaker: SOMAYEH
dialogues.text: My mom and dad never fight.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GHAHRAEI
dialogues.text: Then why were they fighting in your drawing that day? You showed me.

dialogues.speaker: SOMAYEH
dialogues.text: They didn’t fight anymore.  85

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GHAHRAEI
dialogues.text: You’re sure? Somayeh is quiet and does not respond. INT. EXAMINING MAGISTRATE’S OFFICE — DAY Nader and Hojjat are standing in front of the examining magistrate’s desk and Razieh is sitting on a chair.

dialogues.speaker: HOJJAT
dialogues.text: Yesterday he says I didn’t know she was pregnant. Today he says I didn't push her. (to Razieh) Why aren’t you saying anything?

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: (to Nader) You didn’t push me?

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: I grabbed her here and sent her back from the door. And that’s because she was cussing in front of my daughter.

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: When did I cuss at you?

dialogues.speaker: EXAMINING MAGISTRATE
dialogues.text: (to Nader) Then how did she lose the baby?

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: I'd also like to know what really happened.

dialogues.speaker: EXAMINING MAGISTRATE
dialogues.text: Look forget “I got her out of the house but I didn’t push her.” What’s the distance between the door and the stairs? Two or three meters? What else could’ve happened to cause her miscarriage?  86

dialogues.speaker: HOJJAT
dialogues.text: (to Nader) If you hadn’t done anything wrong, why'd you come to the hospital to see what was wrong with her?

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: I came out of decency.

dialogues.speaker: HOJJAT
dialogues.text: Where was your decency when you hit her?

dialogues.speaker: EXAMINING MAGISTRATE
dialogues.text: Was anyone there during the fight?

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: Yes the neighbors were there.

dialogues.speaker: EXAINING MAGISTRATE
dialogues.text: I‘1l order questionings.

dialogues.speaker: HOJJAT
dialogues.text: The neighbors are in it too just like the teacher.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Your honor, he’s been insulting me from the start! I can also...

dialogues.speaker: EXAMINING MAGISTRATE
dialogues.text: (to Hojjat) I’m the one who determines whether they’re together or who’s telling the truth and who's lying. You be quiet on this matter.

dialogues.speaker: HOJJAT
dialogues.text: Sir do you realize his ex-wife has posted his bail?

dialogues.speaker: EXAMINING MAGISTRATE
dialogues.text: Ma’am do you have someone to vouch for you?  87

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: EXAMINING MAGISTRATE
dialogues.text: A government employee or business-owner to vouch for you.

dialogues.speaker: HOJJAT
dialogues.text: What for?

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: I don’t have anyone. It’s just my husband who is unemployed at the moment.

dialogues.speaker: EXAMINING MAGISTRATE
dialogues.text: You need someone to vouch for you. You’ve been accused.

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: (worried) What’ve I been accused of?

dialogues.speaker: EXAMINING MAGISTRATE
dialogues.text: According to the complaint he filed...

dialogues.speaker: HOJJAT
dialogues.text: He had no right to do that!

dialogues.speaker: EXAMINING MAGISTRATE
dialogues.text: She admitted that she tied his father to the bed, locked him up and left.

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: I explained to you why...

dialogues.speaker: HOJJAT
dialogues.text: This poor thing just lost her baby... (to Nader) Aren’t you ashamed? You call yourself a man?

dialogues.speaker: EXAMINING MAGISTRATE
dialogues.text: 88 Sir bring your voice down!

dialogues.speaker: HOJJAT
dialogues.text: For God’s sake why don’t you listen to us? He’s twisting everything. (angry and screaming) He beat my wife and killed my child. What could be clearer? Why do you want to trample ona poor soul’s rights?

dialogues.speaker: EXAMINING MAGISTRATE
dialogues.text: If you disturb the order, I’1l send you to jail for 3 days.

dialogues.speaker: HOJJAT
dialogues.text: I’ve lost everything. You think I fear jail? You should fear God.

dialogues.speaker: EXAMINING MAGISTRATE
dialogues.text: (to his secretary) Call security to send an officer to arrest him. The secretary picks up the phone to make the call. Worrie Razieh goes towards him and stops him rom dialing the number.

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: Sir for the sake of the Qoran, don’t! (to Hojjat) Go out and be quiet.

dialogues.speaker: HOJJAT
dialogues.text: (distraught) Why be quiet? So they can trample my rights? Razieh is trying to get Hojjat out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: HOJJAT
dialogues.text: (on his way out) I worked for ten years with a (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 89 cobbler. They fired me. I filed a thousand complaints, went to a thousand courthouses, after a year of going back and forth, nothing...

dialogues.speaker: EXAMINING MAGISTRATE
dialogues.text: (to his secretary) Call the gate and let them know he’s not to leave. Nader is standing there politely. Hojjat can be heard fro the corridor. INT. CORRIDOR — EXT. THE COURTYARD — DAY Distraught, Hojjat comes out of the room. Worried, Razieh is trying to clam him. All the people present are watchin them and some have gathered around them.

dialogues.speaker: HOJJAT
dialogues.text: I swear on the prophet, I won’t let you trample my rights this time.. I’1l pour gas on myself and set myself on fire at this very courthouse... Grandma Katti has also come forth to watch. Razieh is scared. Termeh and Somayeh who are in the courtyard feedi the little kitten from the day before, are now paying attention to what’s going on inside. An officer has come take Hojjat away.

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: (to the officer) Forgive us. He’1ll calm down now. The officer ignores her and takes Hojjat. With no other choice, Razieh goes back to the examining magistrate’s office. INT. EXAMINING MAGISTRATE’S OFFICE — DAY Worried Razieh comes in. The examining magistrate is writing something down. Nader is still standing in front him.  90

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: (pleading) Your honor, I beg you for the sake of the Qoran and the Martyrs... he’s stressed out.

dialogues.speaker: EXAMINING MAGISTRATE
dialogues.text: I already wrote the order.

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: In the past month, every other day, he’s been in and out of prison. His creditors have deposited his checks. I’ve begged them to let him come out...

dialogues.speaker: EXAMINING MAGISTRATE
dialogues.text: I’ve been patient for the past two days. Razieh puts her hand in her bag and brings out a plastic bag full of pills.

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: I beg you to forgive him. Sir, look at these. Every day he takes a bunch of these. Ever since he lost his job, he’s been depressed. He can’t help it.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Sir can I ask you to please forgive him this time?

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: (to the examining magistrate) You're like his elder...

dialogues.speaker: EXAMINING MAGISTRATE
dialogues.text: Go tell him to find someone to vouch for you...

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: Yes sir!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: and you don’t leave the courthouse.

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: I’1l wait for him to come back. Razieh leaves the room. EXT. COURTYARD — DAY 91 Termeh and Somayeh are seated next to the kitten in a corner of the crowded courtyard. They are speaking to eac other.

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH
dialogues.text: It’s something the size of this cat’s head.

dialogues.speaker: SOMAYEH
dialogues.text: Then how does it kick?

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH
dialogues.text: A four-month-old fetus kicks?!

dialogues.speaker: SOMAYEH
dialogues.text: Yes. I heard it!

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH
dialogues.text: A four-month-old-baby doesn’t even have arms and legs, how can it even kick?

dialogues.speaker: SOMAYEH
dialogues.text: Did you go into my mom's... my mom’s belly and see what it’s like?

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH
dialogues.text: No but in books you can go and see the pictures. It’s a piece of meat like this... She makes a face to look like an unformed fetus. laughs.

dialogues.speaker: SOMAYEH
dialogues.text: Somayeh  92 If it doesn’t have anything, then how did they know it was a boy?

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH
dialogues.text: Was it a boy?

dialogues.speaker: SOMAYEH
dialogues.text: After my mom gave birth to it in the hospital, they found out that it was a boy...

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH
dialogues.text: Did you see it too? Hojjat is on his way out. He speaks to Somayeh. Upon hearing Hojjat’s voice, Termeh does not continue her conversation.

dialogues.speaker: HOJJAT
dialogues.text: Go sit next to your mother. Don’t sit out in the sun. Termeh sees Hojjat’s angry glance. Along with Somayeh, th go inside. Hojjat walks towards the gate. Having gone aft the appraisal of the house, Simin walks in from the opposite direction with documents in her hand. She walks past Hojjat. INT. CORRIDOR — EXT. COURTYARD — DAY Nader and Termeh are sitting on a bench. His hand is stil handcuffed to the hand of an officer. Grandma Katti walks in from the courtyard. She is kindly holding Somayeh’s hand.

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH
dialogues.text: Will you tell her?
