dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: She'll think it’s cause she bailed me out.

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH
dialogues.text: So let her! Dad please!

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: 93 (with no other choice) Okay...

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH
dialogues.text: You promise? Jokingly, Nader raises his hand to swear. His hand is handcuffed to the officer’s hand and raises his hand also

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: (jokingly) Why do you promise? The officer laughs. Grandma Katti and Somayeh walk toward Nader.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDMA KATTI
dialogues.text: Get up! Come and take back the complaint you’ve filed against them. Drop the complaint and let them leave.. poor things... EXT. STREET OUTSIDE THE COURTHOUSE — DAY Termeh and Nader get in their car and drive off.

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH
dialogues.text: Dad!

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH
dialogues.text: You didn’t know Ms. Razieh was pregnant?

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: No. Another period of silence. Nader realizes that Termeh is deep in thought.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Why do you ask?

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH
dialogues.text: It’s nothing.  94

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Then why did you ask?

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH
dialogues.text: Last night mom said you knew.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Where was she to see if I knew?

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH
dialogues.text: She said when they told you at the hospital that Razieh's baby had died, you didn’t say anything. You didn’t ask if she was pregnant. You didn’t get surprised. At times like this, people usually ask if she was carrying a child. It was like you knew. Nader is shocked at Termeh’s words. He stays quiet for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Your mom wants to turn you against me.

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH
dialogues.text: Don’t tell her I told you this. Nader is still quiet. It is clear he is upset. EXT. STREET OUTSIDE GRANDMA KATTI’S HOUSE — DAY Nader’s car pulls over opposite Grandma Katti’s house. On the other side, Simin and her mother get out of their car and walk towards their house.

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH
dialogues.text: Will you tell her? Nader is not sure how to respond to Termeh. He gets out a walks to the other side of the street. Termeh stays in th car. Nader walks across the street and reaches Grandma Katti’s house. He rings the doorbell and enters. Termeh’s anticipating gaze is at the door to Grandma Katti’s house (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 95 Her expression is that of worry. A few moments later, Nader, walks out of the house holding his father’s arm. Grandma Katti walks them to the door. Nader walks his father across the street. He opens the rear passenger doo and helps his father into the back seat. Termeh’s hopeful gaze is still at Grandma Katti’s house. Nader gets in and when he turns the engine on and puts the car into gear, a of Termeh’s hopes dissipate and upset, she turns her gaze out of the window on her side. Nader realizes she is upse

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: I can’t sweetie.

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH
dialogues.text: Didn’t you promise?

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. Nader drives off. A heavy silence falls between them in t car. INT. NADER’S HOUSE — STAIRWAY — DAY Nader is holding his father’s arm and is climbing the stairs. Termeh who is still clearly upset, is climbing ahead of them and has reached the door and is waiting for her grandfather to reach her.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Which step had she fallen on?

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH
dialogues.text: That one down there. Nader turns the key in the lock and opens the door. His gaze is on the stairs and he is deep in thought.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Take him inside, I'll be right in. Termeh takes her grandfather’s hand and takes him in. Nad looks at the stairs. INT. HALLWAY AND MR. MORTEZA’S ROOM — DAY  96 Termeh seats her grandfather on the edge of the bed. He i quiet and helpless like a child. She goes back to the hallway. Something is keeping her preoccupied. She sees Somayeh’s backpack which has been left behind the apartme door. She opens it and from it, she takes out a drawing a looks at it. A childish drawing of a man and a woman. The woman has a protruding belly. From the drawing it can be perceived that the man and woman are fighting. Nader open the door and comes inside. He sees Termeh looking at the drawing. Termeh takes the drawing to her room. Nader, tir of the events of the past two days, takes off his jacket and sinks into the sofa. His gaze is upon his father who clearly less energetic than the week before.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: (to Termeh) Sweetie will you put the kettle on? Without answering, Termeh walks into the kitchen. INT. KITCHEN — DAY Frustrated with the stove’s broken lighter, Termeh lights it with matches. Nader is standing in the kitchen doorway and is looking at her.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: What would you like for lunch? I’1l order in.

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH
dialogues.text: I’m not hungry. Nader walks into the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Are you mad at me?

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH
dialogues.text: What did you go and say to Mrs. Kalani?

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: What do you mean what did I say?

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH
dialogues.text: 97 Why did you go to their house?

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: I told her that they are coming to investigate. To be aware. Is that not okay?

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH
dialogues.text: If she is to tell the truth then why should she be aware? Nader is shocked at Termeh’s response. He realizes what s means.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Come here. I want to show you something.

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH
dialogues.text: I have homework to do.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Leave it. I’m telling you to come. Nader leaves the kitchen. With no other choice, Termeh follows him. INT. STAIRWAY — DAY Nader opens the door to the apartment and walks towards t stairs that lead downstairs. Termeh is perplexed and standing in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: You said she had fallen down here right? Termeh is worried that the neighbors might hear them.

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH
dialogues.text: Okay come inside and explain.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: I don’t want to say anything bad. Okay... pretend that I am that woman... I get thrown from the door in this direction right?  98 Nader moves from the door towards the step on which Razie had fallen. To reach that step, he has to change his direction.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Come. Look. When someone is thrown, they travel straight ahead till they hit something. They don’t turn one way and then turn another way and then come and fall here. Right? If I had thrown her, she should have fallen straight ahead on those stairs up there or ultimately on this first step. Okay imagine that you’ve been pushed, move in this direction... Termeh is deep in thought.

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH
dialogues.text: Then how did she fall down there?

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: I don’t know but she wasn’t thrown on that step. Either she fell on her own or something happened to her afterwards. Termeh is staring at the stairs. Nader goes towards the apartment door.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: You go and stand where I was standing. Look from that spot. Go and stand there. Termeh goes and stands on the stairs leading downstairs where Razieh had fallen.

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH
dialogues.text: (going down the stairs) Why don’t you tell them these things?  99

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: (going inside the house) Forget them. I want you to know. Look for yourself. Nader goes inside and closes the door. Termeh is standing in the stairway deep in thought. INT. BEHIND THE APARTMENT DOOR AND HALLWAY — DAY Nader is standing inside behind the apartment door. He to is preoccupied. Before going out of the door, he sees his father who is standing in the hallway and staring at him. The two look at each other. Nader pushes down on the door handle to open the door. INT. STAIRWAY — DAY The door to Nader’s house suddenly opens and Nader pushes young officer who is trying to keep from being pushed, ou towards the stairway. The young officer stops at the top the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: (to the young officer) Sorry. In the stairway, a police officer holding a piece of pape witnesses this scene. The neighbors including Mrs. Kalani are also standing in the stairway leading to the floor above. Hojjat and Somayeh are standing in the landing of the floor below and Razieh is standing in the middle of t stairway.

dialogues.speaker: POLICE OFFICER
dialogues.text: (to Razieh) Is that the direction he threw you in?

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: No, towards the lower floor.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: 100 Officer, this door doesn’t allow anyone to be pushed towards the lower floor.

dialogues.speaker: POLICE OFFICER
dialogues.text: Where did you fall down?

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: On these stairs.

dialogues.speaker: POLICE OFFICER
dialogues.text: Which step? Razieh doubtingly points out the second step down from Nader’s floor. Hojjat is paying complete attention to everything that is being said.

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: I think it was this one.

dialogues.speaker: POLICE OFFICER
dialogues.text: You think or you’re sure?

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: No I’m not sure.

dialogues.speaker: POLICE OFFICER
dialogues.text: (to Mrs. Kalani) Is this where you found her?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. KALANI
dialogues.text: I didn’t see her fall but when I arrived, she was sitting on that step down there.

dialogues.speaker: HOJJAT
dialogues.text: (to Razieh) Why aren’t you saying anything?!... Go show them how he pushed you.

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: I was so upset that I didn’t realize what was happening.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: (to Hojjat)  101 Look, I’1l stand in her place in he doorway. (to the young officer) You push me out with all the force you want to use. See if I fall where this lady is saying she fell.

dialogues.speaker: HOJJAT
dialogues.text: Of course you won’t fall. She was a pregnant woman. She falls with a touch.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Then you come and stand in your wife’s place. You chose who pushes you. See if you fall on that step.

dialogues.speaker: HOJJAT
dialogues.text: What step?! She says she fell on that step up there.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: They all say they saw her on that one down there.

dialogues.speaker: POLICE OFFICER
dialogues.text: (to the female neighbor) Ma’am did you see her get thrown?

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE NEIGHBOR
dialogues.text: From up there I couldn’t see the door but I saw the stairs when she fell.

dialogues.speaker: POLICE OFFICER
dialogues.text: Can you show me from where you saw? The female neighbor, who is holding a child, goes up the stairs. The police officer follows her.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Maybe she got dizzy and fell.  102

dialogues.speaker: HOJJAT
dialogues.text: (to Razieh) How many times did you use these stairs? Why hadn’t she gotten dizzy before?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. KALANI
dialogues.text: Excuse me. That morning when I saw her here I asked her why there was garbage on the steps. She said she had gotten dizzy and dropped the bag. (to Razieh) Right?

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: My daughter had taken the garbage down.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. KALANI
dialogues.text: You told me you got dizzy...

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Mrs. Kalani, hadn’t she mopped the stairs that day? The stairs were wet. Maybe she slipped and fell.

dialogues.speaker: HOJJAT
dialogues.text: (angry) Jerk! You pushed her and she slipped.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Be respectful! I’m only not saying anything to you in front of your wife and kid.

dialogues.speaker: HOJJAT
dialogues.text: (angry) You’1l eat shit before you say anything!

dialogues.speaker: POLICE OFFICER
dialogues.text: (to Hojjat) Don’t cuss. Take him outside.  103

dialogues.speaker: HOJJAT
dialogues.text: (to the police officer) They have to live with him. Would they say anything against him?

dialogues.speaker: POLICE OFFICER
dialogues.text: If you have evidence that they’re lying then file a complaint.

dialogues.speaker: HOJJAT
dialogues.text: So now they’re telling the truth?

dialogues.speaker: POLICE OFFICER
dialogues.text: Take that up with your examining magistrate. The young officer guides Hojjat towards the stairs. Razie is helpless and she is standing halfway up the stairs and looking at her husband who is being forced down the stair by the young officer. The sound of the neighbors going up the stairs and explaining to the police officer and the shouting and screaming by Hojjat exiting the building can all be heard. Upset, Somayeh is looking at her mother. INT. HALLWAY AND MR. MORTEZA’S ROOM — DAY Somayeh is holding her backpack and is standing in the doorway to the house. She is looking at Mr. Morteza who i coming out of his room. Nader brings Somayeh her drawing book.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Come here... don’t you want you drawing book? Honey don’t get upset at you parents’ and I fighting okay? Here.. come here let me put this in your backpack.

dialogues.speaker: SOMAYEH
dialogues.text: My mom didn’t take any money.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: 104 I know... that’s not why we fought.

dialogues.speaker: SOMAYEH
dialogues.text: Then why did you fight?

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Cause I got upset that she left my dad.

dialogues.speaker: SOMAYEH
dialogues.text: She had gone to the doctor. Nader is surprised at Somayeh’s words and thinks.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Ok honey. Go on... be careful going down the stairs. INT. MEDICAL EXAMINER'S OFFICE — EXAMINATION ROOM — DAY Mr. Morteza is sitting on the examination chair and a middle-aged doctor is reading the piece of paper that Nad has brought form the courthouse. Nader is standing opposi his desk.

dialogues.speaker: MEDICAL EXAMINER
dialogues.text: Based on the court’s request, we'll examine him and write our observations.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: But you are seeing that he can’t talk.

dialogues.speaker: MEDICAL EXAMINER
dialogues.text: Didn’t you say he has Alzheimer’s?

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Yes but he used to say some things.

dialogues.speaker: MEDICAL EXAMINER
dialogues.text: This is not a courthouse. These things you have to prove over there.  105 Nader is upset at hearing the examiner’s response.

dialogues.speaker: MEDICAL EXAMINER
dialogues.text: Has he sustained any physical harm?

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Yes he has bruises...

dialogues.speaker: MEDICAL EXAMINER
dialogues.text: Lay him down on the bed, take off his clothes. Nader walks his father towards the bed and lays him down. He unbuttons his shirt. He untucks his shirt, he thinks f a moment, he changes his mind, puts his father’s shirt ba on and buttons it up. The doctor walks towards them.

dialogues.speaker: MEDICAL EXMAINER
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: I’m not sure his bruises are from when he fell off the bed. EXT. OUTSIDE TERMEH’S SCHOOL — DAY Simin is behind the wheel and is waiting for Termeh to co out of her school. The students are all happy and noisy. They’ve just given their exams and leaving the school and walking towards their parents or their rides home. Termeh comes out of her school. She is looking for her father’s car in the street. Simin sees her and honks. Termeh sees her and quickly rushes towards her mother’s car.

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: Don’t run... slow down. Termeh is worried and from the window speaks to her mothe

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH
dialogues.text: Mom there’s a fight. INT. CORRIDOR — DAY The sounds of an argument and fight are heard from the headmistress’s office. Simin and Termeh quickly walk  106 towards the headmistress’s office. Several of the school children are curious to see what’s going on and are standing in the corridor. Termeh, embarrassed by this situation, waits outside the office and Simin enters. INT. HEDMISTRESS’S OFFICE — DAY A large office with windows facing the courtyard. Mrs. Ghahraei is very scared and is pale. She is standing ina corner. The HEADMISTRESS, VICE-PRINCIPAL and one or two o the staff are also there. Hojjat, upset and distraught, i sitting on a chair. He is holding a Qoran in his hand. Th school JANITOR is standing next to him. It is clear that prior to Simin’s arrival, a huge argument has taken place

dialogues.speaker: VICE-PRINCIPAL
dialogues.text: (to Hojjat) You have a fight, take it to the police.

dialogues.speaker: HOJJAT
dialogues.text: I don’t want to fight with anyone. I just want to speak to this lady.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GHAHRAEI
dialogues.text: (trembling) What do I have to say to you? I don’t know you nor this woman’s husband.

dialogues.speaker: HOJJAT
dialogues.text: If you don’t know him, then why did you come to the courthouse and lie?

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: What lie did she tell?

dialogues.speaker: HOJJAT
dialogues.text: She knows what she said.

dialogues.speaker: HEADMISTRESS
dialogues.text: Ms. Safaei, call the police.

dialogues.speaker: HOJJAT
dialogues.text: Ma’am, don’t scare me with the police.  107

dialogues.speaker: JANITOR
dialogues.text: This isn’t right sir.. please get up and leave.

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: Your fight is with someone else, not with her...

dialogues.speaker: HOJJAT
dialogues.text: If it's not with her, then why does she try to get my daughter to speak?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GHAHRAEI
dialogues.text: I did no such thing.

dialogues.speaker: HOJJAT
dialogues.text: Why did you tell her I hit her mom and she lost the baby?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GHAHRAEI
dialogues.text: When did I say such a thing?!

dialogues.speaker: HOJJAT
dialogues.text: You are a teacher for god’s sake. Aren’t you ashamed? You pick on a 4-year-old’s drawing and tell her her dad hit her mom and she lost the baby? Is that the reason?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GHAHRAEI
dialogues.text: I didn’t say it like that.

dialogues.speaker: HOJJAT
dialogues.text: Why is it that you think my kind beats our wives and children like animals. I swear on this Qoran, we’re humans just like you. Hojjat’s hands are shaking with anger. There’s a moment o silence and everyone is upset about his situation.

dialogues.speaker: JANITOR
dialogues.text: Let’s go outside and get some fresh air. Come on.  108 Hojjat gets up to leave. On is way out he gives Simin an ultimatum.

dialogues.speaker: HOJJAT
dialogues.text: I have nothing else left to lose. Not even my life. He pushes his collar aside and shows them his neck.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL
dialogues.text: Okay sir, leave.

dialogues.speaker: HOJJAT
dialogues.text: (to Mrs. Ghahraei) Ma’am, I’m not going to let you go. I’m unemployed. I’11 stand out there all day. Eventually you'll come out. Come to court and say you lied or I’ll get to the bottom of what’s between you and her husband...

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GHAHRAEI
dialogues.text: (yelling) Shame on you! What do you mean between you?! I keep quiet and you...

dialogues.speaker: HOJJAT
dialogues.text: If there’s nothing why do you help him?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GHAHRAEI
dialogues.text: It was YOU who called and said come to court they have a question for you. I came there and whatever they asked, I told them the truth.

dialogues.speaker: HOJJAT
dialogues.text: If you say you said the truth then place your hand on this and swear.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GHAHRAEI
dialogues.text: (yelling) Fine give me that Qoran! I’m not scared.

dialogues.speaker: HOJJAT
dialogues.text: You said her husband didn’t know my wife was pregnant. Say that! Mrs. Ghahraei comes forward and places her hand on the Qoran that Hojjat has brought with him.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GHAHRAEI
dialogues.text: (yelling) I swear on this Qoran that day at their house, her husband didn’t hear what your wife and I said. He was in the kitchen and didn’t find out that your wife was pregnant from our conversation... Okay? Anything else I should say? Hojjat leaves. Simin is upset and is standing in a corner The vice-principal seats Mrs. Ghahraei, who is still shaking from fear, down on a chair.

dialogues.speaker: HEADMISTRESS
dialogues.text: He’s crazy... (to Mrs. Ghahraei) Don’t leave on your own. Call your husband to come here.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GHAHRAEI
dialogues.text: No... no.. I don’t want him to find out.

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: I’m sorry Mrs. Ghahraei.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GHAHRAEI
dialogues.text: I only went to court out of respect for your husband... If I'd know it would come to this, I wouldn’t have even answered my phone.  110 Mrs. Ghahraei gets up to leave.

dialogues.speaker: VICE-PRINCIPAL
dialogues.text: Where to? He hasn’t left yet!

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GHAHRAEI
dialogues.text: I’m going to wash my face. Mrs. Ghahraei leaves the office. INT. CORRIDOR — DAY (CONT. ) Termeh is behind the office door and it is clear that she has heard everything. Mrs. Ghahraei comes out of the offi and Termeh sees her angry and upset glare. She is ashamed Mrs. Ghahraei leaves. Upset, Termeh walks towards the exi INT. NADER’S HOUSE — HALLWAY — DAY Nader has the receiver to his ear and is waiting for the other end to pick up. He walks through the hallway to the door and opens it for Simin and Termeh and then walks bac to the living room.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Hello? Hello Mrs. Ghahraei. I left you a message earlier. Can you please pick up? (pause) The lady that took care of my dad, apparently that day you gave her the number for a gynecologist. I wanted to ask you for that number to call and see if she went to see the doctor that week and what her problem was. I would appreciate you calling me back. Thank you. INT. KITCHEN — DAY Nader places the tray and dishes in the kitchen sink. He does not pay any attention to Simin. Worried, Termeh come to the kitchen door.

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: What do you want to do?  Nader is upset 111

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: With what?

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: With them.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: You want to have fights and arguments everyday?

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Why what’s happened?

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: He’s gone to her school today and embarrassed her in front of everyone.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: (to Termeh) What did he say?

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH
dialogues.text: He screamed, “Her dad killed my child.”

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: How can she go back to that school? at hearing this.

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: Do you know what you are doing?

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: What I’m doing?

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: He’s making threats.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: He wouldn't dare!  112

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: Termeh honey go to your room and close the door. Reluctantly, Termeh leaves the kitchen and closes the doo

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: What if he kills your child on her way to school?

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: What would you have me do? Run off abroad with you?

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: To hell with abroad! I’m talking to you about my child. What is this situation you’ve created for her?

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: I created? You have some nerve accusing me? Who left home? Who filed for a divorce in the middle of her exams?

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: Didn’t you say leave whenever you want?!

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Yes. Why did you come back? Leave!

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: I will! But first I’m going to see about her situation.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Her situation’s fine.

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: You have two choices...

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Don’t give me an ultimatum.  113

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: It’s not an ultimatum. Either you clear up the situation with them...

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: No I know what to do with them.

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: Didn’t you hit her? Didn’t you throw her on the stairs? Didn’t she lose her baby?

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: (sarcastically) Yes! Yes! I killed her child!

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: So then why are you being stubborn? Pay the blood money and end it.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: I won't be forced into paying.

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: Why forced? Put yourself in their place.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: I’m not responsible for their troubles.

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: (yelling) Their child died!

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: (yelling) And my dad has been hurt! He doesn’t even speak anymore!

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: He didn’t speak much before.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: 114 I was happy with the few words he spoke.

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: You’re comparing this with you causing her miscarriage?

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Where were you to see I caused it?

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: Then how did she lose it?

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: (losing his temper) I don’t know. There might be a chance that her husband did something and now she wants to blame me. Her child said that she had gone to the doctor that day. What had happened that she couldn’t wait 2 hours to go to the doctor? Why did she tie the old man to his bed and leave?

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: The medical examiner said her child died due to a blow!

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: The medical examiner is not God! I won’t accept that I did it till it’s been proven to me.

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: Fine let me take Termeh.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Shame on you for trying to put pressure on me in this situation.

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: I’m worried about my child.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: 115 Your child wants to live here in this society. She has to stay here and learn.

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: Learn what? Fighting and stubbornness?

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: I don’t want her to learn from you and be a coward and afraid every time someone screams. He knows where to come to scream. Why doesn’t he come and threaten me?

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: Yes I’m a coward.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Your whole life, instead of solving problems, you’ve either run away or held your hands up and given in. Just say why you want to leave this country. You're afraid to stay.

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: Oh and you’re staying to fix the country? You couldn’t even manage this house for one week without me.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: I couldn't manage it and I’m responsible.

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: Fine, let me take Termeh and you do what you want.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: I haven’t stopped her from leaving. Nader walks towards the door. He opens it and speaks to Termeh in the living room.  116

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Termeh sweetie, don’t feel like you have to stay. Go wherever you like. Upset, Simin leaves the kitchen. INT. LIVING ROOM AND THE CORRIDOR — DAY (CONT. ) Termeh is seated on a sofa and is thinking about all the things she’s just heard. Simin comes out of the kitchen a walks into the living room. She takes her purse from the sofa.

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: You still don’t want to come?! Termeh does not respond. She does not even raise her head Simin walks towards the door and leaves the house. INT. TERMEH’S ROOM — DAY Nader is busy working with Termeh on her math homework.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: He sells it for 200 tomans a kilo. If he uses 270 kilograms of flour a day... write down 270... how much is his daily income? Meaning how much profit does he earn a day? So how do we calculate this?

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH
dialogues.text: Did you lie? Nader is shocked at hearing Termeh say this.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH
dialogues.text: You lied.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: About what?

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH
dialogues.text: 117 That you said you didn’t know Ms. Razieh was pregnant.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Why do you ask?

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH
dialogues.text: You said you didn’t hear Razieh speak to Mrs. Ghahraei that day.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: That’s right.

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH
dialogues.text: Then how did you know that Mrs. Ghahraei gave her the number for the gynecologist? Isn't that when she gave it to her? Nader is shocked at Termeh’s question and wasn’t expectin it. He doesn’t know what to say. He doesn’t know what answer to give Termeh.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: All right.. if we want to calculate the profit... Nader falls silent for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Your mom was telling the truth... I knew she was pregnant. Termeh raises her head. She is shocked at what her father has just said.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: When they were talking in the living room, I heard everything from the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH
dialogues.text: Then why did you say you didn’t?

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: 118 Do you know what would happen if I'd said I knew? One to three years in prison. I only thought of what would happen to you. Who would you stay with... Termeh doesn’t know what to do.

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH
dialogues.text: If you knew, why did you hit her?

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: I knew she was pregnant but at that moment I didn’t. I had forgotten it. I wasn't paying attention. I don’t know what it was.

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH
dialogues.text: So explain this to them.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: The law doesn’t care about this. Either I knew or I didn’t... Termeh thinks about what her father has just said.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: If you want me to I’1l go and tell them... EXT. STREET OUTSIDE TERMEH’S SCHOOL — NADER’S CAR — DAY Nader is sitting behind the wheel of his car and his fath is in the front side passenger seat. His car reaches the street on which Termeh’s school is. As he turns into the street, he sees Hojjat who is standing by his motorcycle. Worried, Nader stops in front of the school. As he is watching Hojjat in his rearview mirror, the students are leaving the school. Nader notices that several of the students are looking at him. He understands the meaning o their look. Termeh walks through the school gate. Nader’s gaze follows her to his car and in the rearview mirror he is watching to make sure that Hojjat will not do anything Termeh opens the rear passenger door.  119

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Hi sweetie.

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH
dialogues.text: Didn’t I ask you to not come to the front? Nader is hurt by what Termeh has just said. He has no response to her comment. He backs up to make a U-turn. He spots Mrs. Ghahraei’s car passing them on the street. He honks for her to stop. Mrs. Ghahraei keeps driving. Nader gets out.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Mrs. Ghahraei.. Mrs. Ghahraei! Mrs. Ghahraei’s car speeds away. Nader gets in and quickl changes his direction and follows her.

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH
dialogues.text: What do you want with her? Nader does not answer and speeds up. INT. COURTHOUSE - EXAMINING MAGISTRATE’S OFFICE — DAY Nader is standing opposite the examining magistrate’s des He is writing down his complaint. Standing in the doorway are several plaintiffs and accused who are all waiting to see the examining magistrate.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Who’s responsible for my child’s safety now?

dialogues.speaker: EXAMINING MAGISTRATE
dialogues.text: Without a witness there's no case.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: So without a witness I should wait for him to kill her and then come to you?

dialogues.speaker: EXAMINING MAGISTRATE
dialogues.text: 120 How should I know you are telling the truth?

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Why should I lie? Bring my daughter and father here just to lie?

dialogues.speaker: EXAMINING MAGISTRATE
dialogues.text: Is she here now?

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Yes outside. Ask her yourself. I'm afraid to leave her at school. I'm afraid to leave my dad at home. I can’t go to work. My life is a mess. I can’t go to work...

dialogues.speaker: EXAMINING MAGISTRATE
dialogues.text: You didn’t know his wife was pregnant?

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: No I didn’t.

dialogues.speaker: EXAMINING MAGISTRATE
dialogues.text: When she was speaking to your daughter’s teacher you didn’t hear them?

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: No I didn’t.

dialogues.speaker: EXAMINING MAGISTRATE
dialogues.text: You didn’t huh?

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: EXAMINING MAGISTRATE
dialogues.text: You daughter’s teacher came here and revoked her testimony. She says you knew.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: She came here and said I knew?  121

dialogues.speaker: EXAMINING MAGISTRATE
dialogues.text: Yes she came yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Cause he went to the school and threatened her.

dialogues.speaker: EXAMINING MAGISTRATE
dialogues.text: Answer me. Did you hear her or not?

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: No I didn’t hear them.

dialogues.speaker: EXAMINING MAGISTRATE
dialogues.text: Then how did you know she gave her the doctor’s number?

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: My daughter told me.

dialogues.speaker: EXAMINING MAGISTRATE
dialogues.text: What did your daughter say?

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: She said that this woman got the number for a gynecologist from her teacher.

dialogues.speaker: EXAMINING MAGISTRATE
dialogues.text: Go tell your daughter to come in.. and wait outside. With no other choice, Nader goes out of the room. Other plaintiffs and the accused come in with their files as so as Nader leaves. INT. EXAMINING MAGISTRATE’S OFFICE AND CORRIDOR — DAY Nader’s mind is preoccupied. He passes through the manager's office and enters the corridor. He walks toward Mr. Morteza and Termeh who are seated next to each other a bench in the middle of the busy waiting area. Termeh is in her school uniform and has her schoolbag with her. She has a book in her hand though she is not reading it and i looking at a cat wandering through the corridor. Nader walks towards her.  122

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Termeh... honey get up and come. Termeh leaves her bag and book and walks towards Nader.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Go in. He wants to ask you some questions.

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH
dialogues.text: What questions? Nader doesn’t know how to answer Termeh’s question.

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH
dialogues.text: What does he want to ask?

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Nader walks towards the examining magistrate’s manager’s office. Termeh follows him. They are both worried. Mr. Morteza is left sitting by himself. Termeh goes into the room and Nader goes back and sits next to his father. He worried and waiting for Termeh to come back. INT. EXAMINING MAGISTRATE’S ROOM — DAY It is clear that Termeh has walked in while another file being handled. The accused are handcuffed and seated. Termeh is standing next to the examining magistrate’s des

dialogues.speaker: EXAMINING MAGISTRATE
dialogues.text: So what do you have to say?

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH
dialogues.text: You haven’t asked me anything yet?

dialogues.speaker: EXAMINING MAGISTRATE
dialogues.text: Didn’t your dad tell you what I want to ask you?

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: EXAMINING MAGISTRATE
dialogues.text: What grade are you in school?

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH
dialogues.text: Sixth.

dialogues.speaker: EXAMINING MAGISTRATE
dialogues.text: And that day when your teacher came to your house and asked your housekeeper about her pregnancy where you there?

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH
dialogues.text: Not then, I had gone to get my books.

dialogues.speaker: EXAMINING MAGISTRATE
dialogues.text: Then how did you know she got the doctor’s number from your teacher?

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH
dialogues.text: Cause she gave her the number afterwards, when she was leaving.

dialogues.speaker: EXAMINING MAGISTRATE
dialogues.text: She gave it to her in front of you?

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: EXAMINING MAGISTRATE
dialogues.text: Why didn’t you tell your dad sooner?

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: EXAMINING MAGISTRATE
dialogues.text: That she got the doctor’s number from your teacher.

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH
dialogues.text: I didn’t think it was important for my dad to know.

dialogues.speaker: EXAMINING MAGISTRATE
dialogues.text: 123  124 And did you tell your dad or did he hear it?

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH
dialogues.text: When she gave the number... I told him.

dialogues.speaker: EXAMINING MAGISTRATE
dialogues.text: You told him?

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: EXAMINING MAGISTRATE
dialogues.text: Okay. EXT. AND INT. NADER’S CAR — STREET — DAY Nader is behind the wheel and is driving. His father is i the front passenger side seat and Termeh is sitting in th back. Termeh is upset and looking out of the window. Nade notices that she is upset. Termeh is quiet. Nader pulls over. All three are sitting quietly in the car and Nader upset about the turn of events. EXT. TEHRAN BAZAAR — INT. COBBLER’S BLOCK — DAY Simin and Azam, Razieh’s sister-in-law, are walking in th cobbler’s block at the Tehran Bazaar. The bazaar is busy and they turn into one of its many arcades. INT. COBBLER’S WORKSHOP — DAY Azam, Simin and Hojjat are sitting on stools in the middl of a cobbler’s workshop, which seems to have been closed for a long time. All the necessary tools and materials ar there but no one is at work. Mr. Ali, an old man who seem to be the owner is sitting behind an old and faded desk next to a noisy window. His head is resting on the desk a he has fallen asleep.

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: (to Hojjat) I’m afraid of something worse happening because of all these arguments.

dialogues.speaker: AZAM
dialogues.text: 125 Ma’am it’s your husband who is hurting this poor soul.

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: They’re both being stubborn.

dialogues.speaker: HOJJAT
dialogues.text: How’ve I been unfair? What crime have I committed? Was it anything other than the fact that my wife was beaten and my child died?

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: You're right.

dialogues.speaker: HOJJAT
dialogues.text: Your husband is not taking responsibility.

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: I admit that he’s to blame but what’1l all this lead to? One or two years in court for a payment plan for the blood money.

dialogues.speaker: HOJJAT
dialogues.text: That’s what upsets me. Ma’am, why do you think it’s for the money that I am going to court?

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: When did I say such a thing?

dialogues.speaker: HOJJAT
dialogues.text: I know you think this guy is a poor bum who is a con and now that his kid has died he wants to...

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: Why do you have to say such...

dialogues.speaker: HOJJAT
dialogues.text: I know it! We’re a bunch of people with no honor...  126

dialogues.speaker: AZAM
dialogues.text: Let’s hear what she has to say. Mr. Ali, who had fallen asleep behind the desk, wakes up the noise and gets up to get some water from the cooler.

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: There’s no other way. Your child won't come back to life and my husband won't get hanged for this.

dialogues.speaker: AZAM
dialogues.text: She’s right. And besides it’s not like her husband did this on purpose. Upset, Hojjat stands up to leave. Mr. Ali follows him.

dialogues.speaker: MR. ALI
dialogues.text: They’re good people for giving you a solution. Take the money and settle it. You can use it in your situation. End this ordeal.

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: We'll decide on an amount right now and I’1l get my husband’s approval. Hojjat walks towards the door.

dialogues.speaker: HOJJAT
dialogues.text: Now we have to get his approval?

dialogues.speaker: MR. ALI
dialogues.text: You act like you don’t need the money. Take a look at yourself. Hojjat gets upset and goes out of the workshop.

dialogues.speaker: AZAM
dialogues.text: Mr. Ali, don’t let him leave. Mr. Ali follows Hojjat out of the shop.  127

dialogues.speaker: MR. ALI
dialogues.text: (on his way out) So stubborn! Simin is looking at them. Mr. Ali, who has followed Hojja reaches him, stops him and begins talking to him. INT. NADER’S HOUSE — TERMEH’S ROOM — AFTERNOON Simin is sitting on the edge of the bed. She is alone in the house. She is staring at the balcony and the clothing which are on the clothes drier and gently moving in the breeze. She hears the sound of the key being turned in th lock and Nader, Termeh and Mr. Morteza all enter. Simin stands up. She sees her own reflection in the mirror and tries to conceal the sorrow she feels. She is not sure whether to leave the room or wait for Nader and Termeh to come in. Termeh realizes Simin is there and comes to the doorway. Without saying anything, Simin hugs her.

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH
dialogues.text: Will you stay? Simin doesn’t know what to say.

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH
dialogues.text: Mom!

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: Let me speak to him. INT. KITCHEN — AFTERNOON Nader is busy placing the dirty dishes in the dishwasher. He is frustrated by how all the dishes won’t fit. Simin comes into the kitchen and stands next to the balcony. Nader does not acknowledge her presence. Simin doesn’t kn where to start.

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: Come and sit. I want to talk to you.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: I can hear you.

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: 128 I went and spoke to her husband today. Nader is still busy with the dishes.

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: Leave those for a minute. Nader closes the dishwasher door and faces Simin.

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: It was difficult but I managed to get him to agree to take fifteen-million instead of forty. Three five-million toman checks in exchange for his consent.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: (shocked) With whose permission did you promise him money?!

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: I can’t handle the stress of my child’s safety. Just now when you were late, I was dying with worry.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: You didn’t get what I just said. I’m saying why are you interfering?

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: I didn’t come here to fight.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: (frustrated) Oh God why can’t I make her understand?

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: Didn’t you say it was my fault, that I introduced her for the job, that if I hadn’t left none of this would’ve happened? So let me fix it.  129

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: If I pay them, it means I have accepted that it was my fault. He’ll never leave us alone.

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: Do you think he will if you don’t pay?

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Why should I bribe someone who...

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: Pretend it’s my dower that you're paying.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: I would beg and borrow to pay you your dower but extortion, I neither have the money for nor will I pay it.

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: Our child is going through adolescence. She is suffering.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: If she were suffering she wouldn’t have stayed.

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: Why do you think she has stayed? Chosen you? To keep us from separating. She knows I won't go anywhere without her. She is suffering but she will not show it.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: You’11 call them right now and say that my husband says I won't pay until it’s been proven to me that I am responsible.

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: I’1l sell my car.  130

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: I don’t want you to sell your car for my sake.

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: When your child is not important enough for you to pay fifteen million...

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Why are you talking nonsense? Money’s not the issue. I won’t give in till it’s been proven to me that it was my fault.

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: As long as my child’s safety is not guaranteed, I won't...

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: You don’t have the right to do anything...

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: If I hadn’t done anything you'd still be in jail.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: I don’t want to be out because of your mom’s deed. Come to court on Monday and get it back. Nader tries to control himself and to not lose his temper Simin leaves the kitchen and is angry. INT. LIVING ROOM AND CORRIDOR — AFTERNOON (CONT’D) Termeh is sitting on a sofa close to the kitchen. Mr. Morteza has sensed the fighting and has come out of his room and walks towards the kitchen. Simin walks from the kitchen to Termeh’s room. Mr. Morteza follows her.

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: (walking and speaking loudly, (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 131 to Nader) Just say my child isn’t worth fifteen million for me and cut it out with the excuses. Nader comes out of the kitchen. He takes his father’s han and walks him towards the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: (walking towards Termeh) Get up! I won’t let you stay here anymore. It is dangerous. Nader takes his father into the bathroom. He stands in th doorway to the bathroom and looks at Termeh. Termeh doesn know what to do. Simin comes out of Termeh’s room with he things. Termeh stands up. Nader is watching her.

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH
dialogues.text: You said you'd stay.

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: (screaming) I was stupid... get up!

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH
dialogues.text: Fine.. you go downstairs and I’‘1l come too. Simin takes her keys and leaves the house. She is angry. Termeh is sad and walks towards her room. She passes Nade on her way.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Don’t worry daddy. Go there for a few days till your exams are over. You’ll be with grandma. You’1l have more fun.

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH
dialogues.text: Didn’t you say it’s not serious?

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: It got serious.  132 Termeh, who is not expecting to hear this, is suddenly overwhelmed and starts to cry. She walks towards her room Nader leaves his father and follows her.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Termeh... Termeh... sweetheart! Termeh pays no attention to him and walks towards her roo

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: If you cry, I’1ll cry too.

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH
dialogues.text: Why won’t you pay them so that mom will come back?

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Mom’s coming back has nothing to do with this.

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH
dialogues.text: It does. She had come to stay. Her stuff was in the car. I saw them. Termeh goes inside her room and closes the door. The constant sound of the intercom can be heard. Nader comes back to the kitchen. INT. KITCHEN, HALLWAY — EXT. OUTSIDE THE HOUSE — AFTERNOO Nader is upset and conflicted. He is in the kitchen next the balcony and is looking downstairs in the street. He sees Simin’s car parked across the street. The apartment door opens. He looks towards the door. Termeh has opened the door to leave. Mr. Morteza has walked to the door wit her as if to stop her. Termeh leaves her things outside t door and brings Mr. Morteza back inside. Nader is still conflicted and walks to the kitchen door. Termeh again walks to the apartment door and picks up her things.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Termeh... Termeh stops to listen to what Nader has to say.

dialogues.speaker: NADER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: 133 «wif you think I am guilty go tell your mom to come back upstairs. We’ll call them to arrange a meeting to pay them. The intercom rings again. Termeh leaves. Nader goes back the balcony. He looks down at the street and sees Simin w walks back to her car and gets in. He waits to see if Termeh leaves with her mother or stays. Moments later, Termeh gets into her mother’s car and they drive away. Nader seems to be happy that Termeh has not asked her mother to come back upstairs. He leaves the kitchen. INT. LANGUAGE INSTITUTE, STAIRWAY AND CORRIDOR — DAY Razieh and her daughter come up the stairs of a language institute. They enter the institute. All around the reception are classrooms filled with young men and women learning English. The doors to some of the classes are open. Razieh walks in and walks towards the receptionist’ desk.

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: Hello... excuse me is Ms. Rafiee here?

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: She’s teaching.

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: She told me to come at ten.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: Please take a seat. Razieh and her little girl sit and wait. INT. CLASSROOM — DAY Razieh and Simin are seated on two chairs and are facing each other. They are surrounded by empty chairs. A few away, Somayeh is drawing on the blackboard. Razieh is struggling with what she wants to say.

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: I have doubts.

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: (shocked) Didn’t he throw you?

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: Yes... Razieh falls silent.

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: Did something happen afterwards at home?

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: No. Even before that my child wasn’t moving.

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: Before when?

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: Before he pushed me.

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: You mean your child had already died?

dialogues.speaker: RAZEIH
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Maybe. 134 Simin is shocked and is quiet. Razieh is worried and look at Somayeh.

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: Had something happened before it?

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: I’m not sure but the night before I had pain.

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: I was hit by a car. Simin is extremely shocked at what she has just heard. Th are both silent.  135

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: You father-in-law had wandered into the street. I went after him. He was crossing the street to come back. I ran to stop him from getting hit by a car but I got hit instead. The pain started that night.

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: Does your husband know this? Razieh is quiet.

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: Why don’t you come say this in court?

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: Since yesterday when you told him about this money, he’s promised it to his creditors.

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: What’s that got to do with my husband? Come see what’s happened to our life!

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: It's my fault. Yesterday when he said you’ve promised him this money, I got really scared. I called a few people. They all say if I have doubts then it’s a sin to take it.

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: If we don’t want to pay this money we have to prove that my husband is innocent.

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: No please! I made you swear that none of this would leave this room.

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: 136 But your husband won’t leave us alone. I fear for my child.

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: I’m afraid of dirty money coming into my life and something bad happening to my child.

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: What do you suggest we do?

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: Don’t pay this money.

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: Your husband won’t leave us alone. Razieh has no response to this. Simin feels sorry for her helplessness. They are both quiet and Somayeh is busy drawing on the blackboard. INT. HOJJAT’S HOUSE, KITCHEN AND HALLWAY — NIGHT Hojjat’s house is small but clean with white walls. Razie is busy in the tiny kitchen. She is pouring tea in glasse set on a tray. She is anxious and is trying to conceal he worry. Through the door she can see her small hallway whe Somayeh and Termeh are seated next to each other. Somayeh shows her drawing to Termeh. She is happy that Termeh has come to their house. Razieh takes the tray and walks to t hallway. In the hallway, she comes face-to-face with Azam her sister-in-law who has come out of the living room.

dialogues.speaker: AZAM
dialogues.text: Give me that. Bring some plates. Razieh gives her the tea tray. Azam sees that Razieh is worried.

dialogues.speaker: AZAM
dialogues.text: Don’t be afraid. Nothing will happen. Razieh goes back into the kitchen.  137 INT. LIVING ROOM — NIGHT The living room of this small house consists of two interconnected rooms. Blankets have been spread all aroun the edge of the room for guests to sit on. Nader and Simi are seated on one side of the room and Hojjat is seated o the opposite side. A few middle-aged men who are Hojjat’s creditors and acquaintances are also in the room. Azam offers tea to everyone and then sits in a corner.

dialogues.speaker: SIMIN
dialogues.text: (to Hojjat) Tomorrow or the day after... whenever you revoke your complaint, we’ll give you three checks.

dialogues.speaker: MIDDLE-AGED MAN
dialogues.text: God bless you.

dialogues.speaker: MIDDLE-AGED MAN
dialogues.text: Hojjat get a pen and paper so we can write everything down and sign it so that...

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Before we do, I just want to say something...

dialogues.speaker: MIDDLE-AGED MAN
dialogues.text: Say a prayer. Whatever it was, it’s finished now.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: No I have already agreed and will honor my word. I just want his wife and my daughter to be here when I speak.

dialogues.speaker: HOJJAT
dialogues.text: (to Azam) Why doesn’t she come?

dialogues.speaker: AZAM
dialogues.text: (facing the hallway and calling Razieh) Sister...  138

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Would you please also call my daughter?

dialogues.speaker: AZAM
dialogues.text: Young lady.. your father wants you. Everyone is quiet and curious to know what Nader wants to say. Termeh comes in. Nader moves over a little so that s can sit next to him. Razieh and her daughter also come in and sit by the door.

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: (to everyone) Excuse me.

dialogues.speaker: NADER
dialogues.text: Look, before I write the checks, I have a favor to ask of you. Ma’am you are a devout person. Please bring a Qoran and place your hand on it and swear that I caused your miscarriage. Razieh is shocked at hearing Nader say this. Simin who wa not expecting such a request is worried.

dialogues.speaker: MIDDLE-AGED MAN
dialogues.text: Go bring a Qoran.

dialogues.speaker: HOJJAT
dialogues.text: (to Azam) Go get it. Before Azam can get up, Razieh stands up and leaves the room. INT. KITCHEN — NIGHT Razieh is frustrated and is standing in their small kitch and is deeply conflicted. She doesn’t know what to do. Worried, Azam comes to the doorway holding a Qoran.

dialogues.speaker: AZAM
dialogues.text: 139 Come back quick or they’11l suspect something. Razieh is stressed and is looking at her.

dialogues.speaker: AZAM
dialogues.text: His creditors are here for the money. For the martyrs’ sake, don’t ruin our reputation.

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: I won’t swear. Azam is wondering how to convince her to go back. Hojjat walks in not knowing what’s happening.

dialogues.speaker: HOJJAT
dialogues.text: Why aren’t you coming? Razieh is afraid to answer.

dialogues.speaker: AZAM
dialogues.text: She’s afraid to swear. Hojjat looks at Razieh in disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: I have doubts. Upon hearing this, Hojjat panics. He closes the kitchen door so that they are not heard. Azam stays out of the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: HOJJAT
dialogues.text: (panicking) Why are you saying this now?!

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: I had told Azam.

dialogues.speaker: HOJJAT
dialogues.text: (frustrated) Why don’t you tell me exactly what happened?!

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: The day before it, a car hit me and that night I had a lot of pain.  140 Hojjat is thinking of what to do.

dialogues.speaker: HOJJAT
dialogues.text: It'll be my sin.

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: No. It's a sin. I asked.

dialogues.speaker: HOJJAT
dialogues.text: They’ve consented to pay it.

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: I am scared that we'll be punished.

dialogues.speaker: HOJJAT
dialogues.text: (tense) More punished than this? (pleading) Take a look at my situation. Have mercy on me.

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: I’m afraid of something bad happening to our child.

dialogues.speaker: HOJJAT
dialogues.text: But you’re the one being cruel to her now. Hojjat approaches Razieh pleadingly to take her out of th kitchen. His behavior is not normal.

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: I swear to God I can’t! Suddenly Hojjat starts to quietly beat himself like a madman. Razieh tries to hold his hands. Hojjat has lost a control. He is angry and leaves the kitchen. Worried, Razieh leaves the kitchen after him. INT. HALLWAY AND LIVING ROOM — NIGHT Hojjat leaves. Upset, Razieh passes through the hallway a walks to the living room where Nader, Simin, Termeh and t rest of the guests are sitting. In the doorway she faces Simin and speaks.  141

dialogues.speaker: RAZIEH
dialogues.text: Ma’am why did you come here tonight? Didn’t I tell you not to come? Didn’t I tell you this money is dirty I don’t want it? Why did you do this to me? How will I live in this house? I swear to God, I will never forgive you! In tears, Razieh leaves the room. Nader looks at Simin in disbelief. Somayeh and Termeh are quietly staring at each other. EXT. OUTSIDE HOJJAT’S HOUSE — NIGHT Nader’s car is parked in an open area close to the street where Hojjat’s house is located. All the car windows are broken or shattered. Nader, Simin and Termeh have reached their car and are shocked at seeing this scene. Upset, Nader opens the car door and removes the shattered glass from the seats. A piece of glass cuts his hand. He wraps tissue around his bleeding hand and gets in. INT. NADER’S CAR, EXT. STREET — NIGHT Nader’s car moves through the streets of the southern par of the city. Through the glassless windows, the wind blow through the car. They keep driving and Termeh is deep in thought. INT. FAMILY COURT, COURTROOM — DAY It is the following season. From the view outside the window it is clear that the weather is cloudy and it is raining. Nader and Simin are seated on two chairs facing the judge. They are dressed head to toe in black winter clothing. It is clear from the length of Nader’s beard th he has not shaved it for a few months. They are both quie and the judge is reading their petition. A few moments of peace and quiet ensue. INT. CORRIDOR — DAY Termeh is sitting alone in the busy corridor. She is wearing a black cardigan over her school uniform for the (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 142 new school term. She is deep in thought. Nader comes and takes her into the judge’s room. Termeh stands in front o the judge. Her parents are on either side. Nader is standing and Simin is still sitting.

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Hello. So young lady, your parents have left it up to you to decide whom you want to live with. Termeh is struggling to answer.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Have you decided? Nader and Simin are trying to pretend to be calm but are both worried about her answer.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: So what is it?

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH
dialogues.text: Do I have to say it now?

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: If you haven't decided...

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH
dialogues.text: Yes I have.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: And? Termeh is uncomfortable by her parents’ presence.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Do you want them to wait outside if it’s difficult for you?

dialogues.speaker: TERMEH
dialogues.text: Can they?  143

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: (to Nader and Simin) Please wait outside. Simin and Nader, who are both upset about their daughter being placed in such a position, leave the room. They pas the secretary’s room and come to the corridor. They each stand in a corner and lean against the wall. They are bot concerned about the answer that Termeh will give and they are worried.
